text:
Criterion of falsifiability
philosophy of science
   
WRITTEN BY
The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica
Encyclopaedia Britannica's editors oversee subject areas in which they have extensive knowledge, whether from years of experience gained by working on that content or via study for an advanced degree....
See Article History
Criterion of falsifiability, in the philosophy of science, a standard of evaluation of putatively scientific theories, according to which a theory is genuinely scientific only if it is possible in principle to establish that it is false. The British philosopher Sir Karl Popper (1902‚Äì94) proposed the criterion as a foundational method of the empirical sciences. He held that genuinely scientific theories are never finally confirmed, because disconfirming observations (observations that are inconsistent with the empirical predictions of the theory) are always possible no matter how many confirming observations have been made. Scientific theories are instead incrementally corroborated through the absence of disconfirming evidence in a number of well-designed experiments. According to Popper, some disciplines that have claimed scientific validity‚Äîe.g., astrology, metaphysics, Marxism, and psychoanalysis ‚Äîare not empirical sciences, because their subject matter cannot be falsified in this manner.

This article was most recently revised and updated by Matt Stefon, Assistant Editor.


Karl Popper
Karl Popper
‚Ä¶what he called the ‚Äúfalsifiability criterion.‚Äù Under this method, a scientist seeks to discover an observed exception to his postulated rule. The absence of contradictory evidence thereby becomes corroboration of his theory. According to Popper, such pseudosciences as astrology, metaphysics, Marxist history, and Freudian psychoanalysis are not empirical sciences,‚Ä¶




WRITTEN BY
The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica
Encyclopaedia Britannica's editors oversee subject areas in which they have extensive knowledge, whether from years of experience gained by working on that content or via study for an advanced degree....
See Article History
Law of nature, in the philosophy of science, a stated regularity in the relations or order of phenomena in the world that holds, under a stipulated set of conditions, either universally or in a stated proportion of instances. (The notion is distinct from that of a natural law‚Äîi.e., a law of right or justice supposedly derived from nature.)

Laws of nature are of two basic forms: (1) a law is universal if it states that some conditions, so far as are known, invariably are found together with certain other conditions; and (2) a law is probabilistic if it affirms that, on the average, a stated fraction of cases displaying a given condition will display a certain other condition as well. In either case, a law may be valid even though it obtains only under special circumstances or as a convenient approximation. Moreover, a law of nature has no logical necessity; rather, it rests directly or indirectly upon the evidence of experience.

Laws of universal form must be distinguished from generalizations, such as ‚ÄúAll chairs in this office are gray,‚Äù which appear to be accidental. Generalizations, for example, cannot support counterfactual conditional statements such as ‚ÄúIf this chair had been in my office, it would be gray‚Äù nor subjunctive conditionals such as ‚ÄúIf this chair were put in my office, it would be gray.‚Äù On the other hand, the statement ‚ÄúAll planetary objects move in nearly elliptical paths about their stars‚Äù does provide this support. All scientific laws appear to give similar results. The class of universal statements that can be candidates for the status of laws, however, is determined at any time in history by the theories of science then current.

Several positive attributes are commonly required of a law of nature. Statements about things or events limited to one location or one date cannot be lawlike. Also, most scientists hold that the predicate must apply to evidence not used in deriving the law: though the law is founded upon experience, it must predict or help one to understand matters not included among those experiences. Finally, it is normally expected that a law will be explainable by more embracing laws or by some theory. Thus, a regularity for which there are general theoretical grounds will be more readily called a law of nature than an empirical regularity that cannot be subsumed under more general laws or theories.

Get a Britannica Premium subscription and gain access to exclusive content.
Subscribe Now
Universal laws are of several types. Many assert a dependence between varying quantities measuring certain properties, as in the law that the pressure of a gas under steady temperature is inversely proportional to its volume (see Boyle‚Äôs law). Others state that events occur in an invariant order, as in ‚ÄúVertebrates always occur in the fossil record after the rise of invertebrates.‚Äù Last, there are laws affirming that if an object is of a stated sort it will have certain observable properties. Part of the reason for the ambiguity of the term law of nature lies in the temptation to apply it only to statements of one of these sorts of laws, as in the claim that science deals solely with cause and effect relationships, when in fact all three kinds are equally valid.

This article was most recently revised and updated by Brian Duignan, Senior Editor.

text: Bill, I think you've done a great dis-service to Natural Climate Change, from the "little" changes in Solar output and Earth's orientation and path through space...Since "The Most Recent Ice Age", Sea Level has risen 5,200 inches (133 meters or 433 feet), and during the Industrial Age (no more a revolution that the Bronze or Iron Ages), of almost 10 inches, (a bit more than you've stated)...So, Natural Climate Change has resulted in 99.8% of the total rise, potentially human effect is 0.2%.  Bill, being a fellow Professional Engineer, I think you'll agree that a 0.2% change (10 inches out of 5,200 inches) is really not significant.  Rise rate is 26 inches/century from Nature, 7 inches/century during our life-extending Industrial Age.  Let's not "throw out the baby with the bath water". text:
Climate change is a real and serious issue. In the past most of it was caused by orbital variation, its most characterised by an abrupt increase in the earths temperature 1.2-1.4¬∞F warmer in the last century. 10 out of the last 13 years were the warmest on record. 97% of climate scientists agree that these aren't caused by the variation in the earths orbit but rather by human activities. Excessive greenhouse gasses due to advancements in technology ‚Äì burning fossil fuels for manufacturing. Traps heat radiating from the sun. Sea risen by 0.3¬∞F since 1969. Bad for sea life. Ocean surface acidity risen by 30% since late 18th century. Calcifying species (oysters, clams, corrals)  at risk, food web at risk. 1 Billion people relying on ocean for protein. Sea levels rising, ice melting. Since 1994 each year on average the earth has lost 400 billion tons of ice from its glaciers. Increased chance of natural disasters. 

How to mitigate ‚Äì Recycle, reuse, walk or use public transport, turn off electronics, eat less meat, eat local food, spread knowledge.

text:
Lets put this simply. Are carbon levels, and global temp rising? Yes, there is evidence they are. Are these directly, and solely from human activity? That is the question that is not proven yet. You need to isolate out that humans are directly causing the temp rise, and nothing else. Obviously humans are the sole cause of the higher carbon levels. What if earth/sun have drifted a tiny amount? What if the atmosphere thickness of layers is allowing slightly more solar wind or radiation through to earth? What if trees/plants are not recycling CO2 as efficiently? So many factors and without ruling them out how do you prove its humans as the direct and sole cause? Its not proven. The temp rising can occur for many many reasons beyond CO2 levels
I dont think climate change being a direct and sole result of human activity is proven yet. Correlation sure, but causation is not yet proven.

Q2.. do you think that human activity is a significant contributing factor?

text:
What I've read is, Water vapor and greenhouse gases, absorb IR  photons sending most of them back into space cooling the earth by reducing the sun's heat that is able to make it to the earth's surface.  

@t

"Just as the major atmospheric gases (oxygen and nitrogen) are transparent to incoming sunlight, they are also transparent to outgoing thermal infrared. However, water vapor, carbon dioxide, methane, and other trace gases are opaque to many wavelengths of thermal infrared energy."

"When greenhouse gas molecules absorb thermal infrared energy, their temperature rises. Like coals from a fire that are warm but not glowing, greenhouse gases then radiate an increased amount of thermal infrared energy in ALL DIRECTIONS".

"Because greenhouse gas molecules radiate heat in ALL DIRECTIONS, some of it spreads downward and ultimately comes back into contact with the Earth‚Äôs surface, where it is absorbed. The temperature of the surface becomes warmer than it would be if it were heated only by direct solar heating. This supplemental heating of the Earth‚Äôs surface by the atmosphere is the natural greenhouse effect."

Up high or down low, I don't see any difference if NASA is correct.  

At the height of the Atmosphere, the Earth constitutes 1/3rd of the space. So the IR absorbed by the ghg, both for incoming sun heat and emitted Earth heat, will be absorbed then emitted in "all directions".  1/3rd will hit the Earth below and the other 2/3rds will go into space. 

Of the Earth emitted heat, 1/3rd of that will be absorbed by the ghgs going out, and sent back to the earth adding additional warming to the earth, this warming is the greenhouse effect according to NASA.

So, water vapor and the ghgs, cool the earth by blocking out 66.4% of Sun heat, while keeping in only 11% (1/3rd of 1/3rd).  The atmosphere keeps out six times more heat than it keeps in.

If we add more molecules of CO2 they will absorb more entering sun heat and cool the earth more than they do now.  With the earth getting less heat, there will be less heat to keep in, so the GHE should fall.  

I don't see how, if NASA is correct, we can be warming the planet by adding more CO2 to the atmosphere.

text:
I do have a question though. In my weather and atmosphere class that recommended this video, we were told: 
"The elements that control major features of the Earth's climate have not always been the same as they are presently. In fact, they have been drastically different in the past. These "past climates"...have ranged from biologically friendly conditions (similar to today) to conditions that were incredibly inhospitable to life! Thus, knowing the Earth's past climates is important to understanding:

How our current climate, and its underlying elements, formed.
Why past lifeforms may have become extinct.
Which current lifeforms dominate the modern landscape. etc."

I know there is a resilience factor involved in the recoverability of ecosystems, but if the above is true, why would Bill Nye say that the changes we are causing to our planet are irreversible? What good would small changes make? We would need drastic changes (for example if everyone went back to living like we were in the Stone Age). How and why would scientists believe that the changes are irreversible? Would there not be there not be some sort of cyclical correction, eventually? Even if it was in thousands of years from now?  Especially if it got so bad that most of humanity was wiped out.
author: Lee Hitt

text:
Get rid of our creature comforts, vehicles and electronics. 
Stop trying to go into outer space, or using air travel. 
Get rid of plastics and fossil fuels. 
Farm less, get rid of synthetic fertilizers and go back to natural growing cycles and grow what is supported by the local climate. 
Use natural materials that can be recycled back into the earth. 
Eat less meat, go back to hunting and gathering and subsistence lifestyle. 
So in other words, we need to de-evolve as a society and go back to the stone age. All the while we thought we were "advancing" as a species, we were really just killing our planet.

text: Dundoril  Do some research - the ‚Äòice age‚Äô theory was pushed back in the 70‚Äôs and 80‚Äôs. I didn‚Äôt make it up. Sorry, but most climate scientist are  being paid to prove the global warming hypothesis, not disprove it. Scientists are getting funding to prove a result based on a single variable. Remember, climate change is not based upon empirical evidence, it‚Äôs based on computer simulation models. It‚Äôs a fact that those models have been wildly inaccurate - hence the Al Gore predictions which never happened. Keep an open mind and don‚Äôt believe everything you see and hear. BTW - I‚Äôm completely on board with sustainability and reducing carbon - I just don‚Äôt like being lied to based on self-serving motives.

text:
The video showing the edge of the iceberg breaking off is natural and is called calving. 

Ideas came about in the early 1900's and late 1800's, but Roger Revelle who was director and oceanographer of Scripts Institute came out with a paper in 1957 about CO2 emissions and it's possible effects on oceans, environments, and the atmosphere. Al Gore Jr. is a notable activist who was a student of his. As we all know, Al Gore effectively campaigned for the idea of global warming. ABC even did a special in 2009 where the documentary was supported by contemporary scientists in the productions of the documentary. In the special, they predicted that by 2015, Las Vegas would be abandoned due to hundreds of miles of fires and Miami would be completely flooded out. 
Back to Roger Revelle, in 1988, he began attempts to disseminate new papers and essays that doubts his own idea of CO2 emissions. He developed an about mindset on the entire situation, but anthropogenic global warming (AGW) theory supporters either denied or missed these later papers by Revelle. Now, scientists in service to the UN's IPCC and nations around the world base most of their research off of this controversial paper, which does not contain confirmed validity.
Also, the Climate Research Unit of East Anglia in the UK had emails exposed by hackers that proved scientists were finding new "tricks" to display data in favor of the AGW movement. NASA in 2015 admitted that there was a "flattening" in warming temperatures from 1990-2015, indicating that temperatures were no longer rising.

How many humans and animals are increasing every minute? Do you agree that we are now over populated? text:
I am a strong advocate for reducing pollution of our planet and humans have everything to do with this problem. I also believe that climate change is real. However, the notion that humans are the cause (anthropogenic), or even a significant factor for affecting climate change is ridiculous and nothing more than fake science. The solar cycles are the cause of the warming and cooling phases of the planet. There is irrefutable evidence of this in real science. One example of the lies we have been fed is that CO2 (carbon dioxide) levels have been on the increase because of humans and this so-called ‚Äúgreen house gas‚Äù raises the temperatures of the planet. Actually, what Al Gore and the fake science has told you is totally false. CO2 levels do not go up first (leads) causing a rise in earth temperatures. Exactly the opposite is true because rises in CO2 levels actually LAG increases in temperature by approximately 600 years due to the outgassing of CO2 from the oceans when seawater temperatures increase due to solar radiation. Thousands of years ago, CO2 levels were above 3000 ppm and now they are lower than 500 ppm. This is actually bordering on the lowest levels that can sustain plant life in our biosphere. If anything, we need more CO2, not less.

Part of me wants to stay silent because I welcome anything that encourages the reduction of environmental pollution and disclosure of new energy and transportation technologies from our classified military industrial complex black projects. These technologies would make combustion of hydrocarbon fuels obsolete but also destroy the backing of our currency / economic system by reducing the value of the petrol-dollar. Oil is the only commodity propping up our US currency today which is why we don‚Äôt see the disclosure and adoption of new technologies that have already been invented.

Please, please, please educate yourselves with the truth. Question everything you hear or read and research for yourselves. Here are some links to help you get started on your own investigation.

text:
1 Natural as well as anthropogenic factors cause warming.
2. Warming is far slower than predicted.
3. Climate policy relies on inadequate models.
4. CO2 is not a pollutant. It is a plant food that is essential to all life on Earth. Photosynthesis is a blessing. 
More CO2 is beneficial for nature, greening the Earth: additional CO2 in the air has promoted growth in global plant biomass. 
It is also good for agriculture, increasing the yields of crops worldwide.
5. Global warming has not increased natural disasters.
6. Climate policy must respect scientific and economic realities.
7. There is no climate emergency. Therefore, there is no cause for panic.

text:
‚Äã¬†@Martin Hearn¬† - Ideas came about in the early 1900's and late 1800's, but Roger Revelle who was director and oceanographer of Scripts Institute came out with a paper in 1957 about CO2 emissions and it's possible effects on oceans, environments, and the atmosphere. Al Gore Jr. is a notable activist who was a student of his that participated in the research for this paper. As we all know, Al Gore effectively campaigned for the idea of global warming. ABC even did a special in 2009 where the documentary was supported by contemporary scientists in the productions of the documentary. In the special, they predicted that by 2015, Las Vegas would be abandoned due to hundreds of miles of fires and Miami would be completely flooded out. 
Back to Roger Revelle, in 1988, he began attempts to disseminate new papers and essays that doubts his own idea of CO2 emissions. He developed an about mindset on the entire situation, but anthropogenic global warming theory supporters either denied or missed these later papers by Revelle. Now, scientists in service to the UN's IPCC and nations around the world base most of their research off of this controversial paper, which does not contain confirmed validity.
author: Marcus Venturini

text:
The video showing the edge of the iceberg breaking off is natural and is called calving. 
Ideas came about in the early 1900's and late 1800's, but Roger Revelle who was director and oceanographer of Scripts Institute came out with a paper in 1957 about CO2 emissions and it's possible effects on oceans, environments, and the atmosphere. Al Gore Jr. is a notable activist who was a student of his. As we all know, Al Gore effectively campaigned for the idea of global warming. ABC even did a special in 2009 where the documentary was supported by contemporary scientists in the productions of the documentary. In the special, they predicted that by 2015, Las Vegas would be abandoned due to hundreds of miles of fires and Miami would be completely flooded out. 
Back to Roger Revelle, in 1988, he began attempts to disseminate new papers and essays that doubts his own idea of CO2 emissions. He developed an about mindset on the entire situation, but anthropogenic global warming (AGW) theory supporters either denied or missed these later papers by Revelle. Now, scientists in service to the UN's IPCC and nations around the world base most of their research off of this controversial paper, which does not contain confirmed validity.
Also, the Climate Research Unit of East Anglia in the UK had emails exposed by hackers that proved scientists were finding new "tricks" to display data in favor of the AGW movement. NASA in 2015 admitted that there was a "flattening" in warming temperatures from 1990-2015, indicating that temperatures were no longer rising.

text:
¬†@OSO POLAR MOVIES¬† The last ice age was 2.6 million years ago and the CO2 levels have constantly fluctuated since then. Both rising and falling. Normal cycles nothing to worry about because most of it happened before humans could cause any real impact. Look at those cycles before the industrial revolution and then compare it to the data after and you will see they look nothing alike. The fact they changed drastically after the industrial revolution should tell you that it probably not a natural occurrence.

Water levels have been raising since the last ice age at an average of 6 cm per century after the ice age, again this is considered normal but since the 20th century the average has increased to 20 cm. Again as the same with CO2 this shows a clear deviation from what is considered natural. 

The best part with both of these is that you can actual take these measurements yourself. If you don't believe it with a little money and a road trip to the coastline periodically and a reasonable understanding of how to take proper measurements you can compile this data yourself. Granted if you cant trust NOAA, NASA and all the other worlds scientists and organizations who take these readings then you cant really trust anyone even if they agree with you and should actual take these measurements yourself.

text:
¬†@Gary Ha¬† I see your point, and that you do have good intent, but you're clearly making a mistake. Don't just take the last 140 years, because that speed isn't nearly as fast as the last 10 years. Additionally, those websites say "appear to be" because they don't want to be held responsible if they're even slightly wrong. Many species that have died from global warming haven't died from just the temperature increase. Many species have died from events like the Australia fires, which was caused by climate change. Hope this helps.
I only called you out on not researching because you replied to me after 13 minutes,  which was about how long it would take for you to write your reply.
Also, yes, human population growth has effected this, because with more humans, there is more greenhouse gasses. The demand for products that require the release of CO2 to be made increase.
What I'm saying is, your range for temperature increase is too large and naturally selected, you didn't research for long enough, the temperature increase isn't all that's killing entire species, and 140 million people every year does contribute to climate change.
Hope this helps.
author: MeowPau

text:
Bill Nye, you don't know the first thing about the science of the so called "greenhouse effect" hypothesis.  Let me help you there son. An hypothesis is pure conjecture and therefore, the farthest you can possibly be from settled science.  Here is a bit of real science for you!
The IPCC claim that CO2 is a so called "Greenhouse Gas" because it has strong IR absorption and emission bands at 15¬µm. 
According to Wien's displacement law, 15¬µm radiation has a corresponding temperature of minus -80¬∫ C. 
The troposphere, (that's the bit of the atmosphere we live in) is defined by molecules which have a temperature of minus -60¬∫ C and above. 
IR emissions from CO2 @ 15¬µm cannot heat any molecules in the troposphere, it would be a violation of the laws of thermodynamics and is impossible.¬† 
Outside of the 15¬µm absorption and emission bands, CO2 is indistinguishable from the rest of the molecules in the air, in accordance with the ideal gas law. 
When they say that the "greenhouse effect is settled science", the truth is 180¬∫ the opposite. 
The so called "greenhouse effect" is an hypothesis i.e. pure conjecture. Nothing could be further from being settled science. 
The "greenhouse effect" hypothesis is and always has been, as I have stated above, a contravention of the laws of physics and therefore completely at odds with the "settled science".

text:
CO2 is what plants breathe. Greenhouses on farms are pumped full of CO2 because it makes the crops grow faster, bigger, and with more nutrients. Corn has been hitting all time highs for yields for the last 5 years according to NOAA's raw data sets. When the first explosion of life happened on Earth there was over 7000ppm CO2 in the atmosphere. Today we are around 400. Almost 20 times less. More CO2 means more oxygen which means more thriving life and more plants. That is a real snowball affect, unlike the "greenhouse affect." It is estimated by some scientists such as Dr. Patrick Moore that if we go below 150ppm atmospheric CO2 concentration, then all plant life will be unable to survive. We hit the lowest that we ever have in recent history, (past 500 years) and we are still on the extremely low end for atmospheric CO2 concentration. There is no downside to atmospheric CO2. In fact it is what keeps all life on Earth alive. And fossil fuels keep all of us alive when it gets too hot or too cold outside. It is what allows us to live with luxuries in life instead of like cavemen. 


The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere is controlled by the temperature. Not the other way around. When your water soda or beer gets warmer, more CO2 bubbles form and rise to the surface and are released into the atmosphere. Antarctic ice core data shows that CO2 levels and temperature have been parallel for the past 450,000 years. But CO2 lags temperature by 800 years. This is because of the heat cycles in the ocean. CO2 has a greenhouse affect on 3 electromagnetic radiation wavelengths. Water vapor has a greenhouse affect on more than 50, including the 3 that CO2 also has a possible affect on. All of those 3 wavelengths are already being held in the atmosphere. More CO2 will have a practically unnoticeable affect, if any. 


NOAA and NASA's current graphs and published data sets go against their previous data and raw data sets. The difference between a raw data set and a published one is that the raw data set is the pure data. It has not been altered or changed at all. The newer published data sets have more than 50% of the raw data replaced with either algorithm generated data or simply human inputted numbers, and they show the opposite of what the raw data shows. 


None of the predictions of these "scientists" have come true, and anyone can take a look outside and see that these wild claims about "60% of wildlife has been killed since 1970" or "Snow will be a thing of the past by 2020" are completely false. Anyone can go to a legitimate organisation such as the DMI (Danish Meteorological Institute) and look at real data that goes completely against what groups with corrupt management say. Or they can take a look at NOAA's maps and raw data sets. Alaska is not having record heat right now like the media are reporting. It is -65% in some places there right now. The forecasts are all available online. 


Climate models from climate "scientists" have never been needed, because we have geologists and paleontologists. They know the history of the earth and have studied what happens during circumstances such as the current one today. We do not need these predictions, because we already have data that has fairly closely repeated itself, and laws based on that data. That is how you do science, data. All of what I sat has been preached by real scientists for decades, and the actual number of scientists that believe in global warming is around 3%. Not 97%.

text: Hmm...as one point of criticism; re the comment about the Arctic having lost 36 cubic miles of ice in a 4-yr period (2002-2005) - that amounts to a frightening(?-?) one ten millionth(!) of the volume of the ocean, (over 330 million cubic miles of it) and since that stated loss is massively within the normal, fluctuant annual gain/loss cycles of the Arctic ice, which has gained a good deal more than it lost in the last three years, and as the Arctic comprises about 10% of the ice on the poles, the 36 cubic miles of loss (since more than gained back) does not exactly terrify me...give us some context please! Meanwhile the Antarctic, a far more important frozen entity, appears to be accrueing net ice gains in most recent years, especially in its eastern portions, which comprise 98% of its 90% share in the global polar ice budget....Seas are "not" showing an increased "rate" (key operative word) during any time since we have had tide gages in place. The seas are rising, yes, that is all we have seen them do curing our competent observation window, but at the same millimeter or two a year rate that we have been observing since the 1880's....that Nye is still marching out the bogus 97% "consensus", (a word not to applied to scientific conclusions, and generated from shamefully corrupted data inputs from an Aussie's (Cook) mere Master's thesis) and simplifying if not bastardizing alleged, significant CO2 greenhouse effects works great in a 10-gallon, closed system aquarium tank) as one of about 17 climatic inputs to be considered - well it is just hard to take his points of argument seriously. I'm happy to be concerned with the subject and to listen to intelligent arguments, but the sheer tonnage of scientific drivel out there is breathtaking - not that CO2 has anything to do with affecting my personal air quality. - Back to the kiddo shows Nye.

text:
If you want to quit believing in catastrophic climate change that is going to end all humankind because we're using fossil fuels. Pull the data for the percent of days above 32C (90F) each year for the years as back as far as you can from as many credible sources that you can. I used all US Historical Climatology Network Stations from 1918 to 2018. And compared that with the carbon based fuel consumption in the same years, (what some people call fossil fuels). There's no climate change from an increase in CO2 in the atmosphere. 
Also do a mass balance on the carbon cycle, no catastrophic climate change from carbon-based fuels again.

text:
Its hard to say exactly how much we are causing an effect but to say we are doing nothing is not true. I am taking a geology class and looking at geological records almost never has change ever happened at the rates we see now without some crazy cataclysm like a mass extinction happening. The problem is how accurately we can calculate this change in the past, which is not easy. Its not easy but looking at what can be causing today's rapid temperature change and the possible causes humans are the most likely. As this guy said in the video the planets orbit usually was the major factor for past warming and cooling but we can directly observe the current orbit of the planet and see that it is not what is causing it at least not to this extent. We can look at geological events like valcanism
and see it been relatively stable and the other factors are mostly human related. Am i saying we are dooming the planet? No, but the fact we do have an impact is not really debatable if you just look at the data for yourself. The NASA GISS data is a good place to start as well as looking at geological data to compare to the past.


Form your own conclusion rather if you dont trust this guy and unless your dad is reasonably educated in science in general take his word with caution. The worry isnt really about the warming to me but if the ice caps melt will they ever come back and thats hard to say. Its very possible they wont if we keep our pollution output. CO2 is why Venus is the hottest (average) planet in our solar system. Dinosaurs ruled for millions of years and we humans only have a history that goes back thousand. Would be a shame for us to go away so fast giving all we can do. Our history on earth is insignificantly small when looking a geological time. Would to error on the side of caution not be smart?

text: ¬†@DriveJapan¬† Humans contribute roughly about 0.01% to global warming. Just in the last 600 million years, the Earth has seen CO2 levels 20x what they are today, during glacial periods no less. This data seems to suggest that CO2 is not a driving force, especially when you try to correlate CO2 to climate, CO2 always turns out to be a lagging indicator. Bottom line, while we do contribute a negligible amount to the warming, we have no control over the climate. Only political ambition that plays upon Human hubris allows this myth to perpetuate.
author: Steve Smith

text: ¬†@DriveJapan¬† Venus is not hot because of CO2. CO2 can only account for about 15C of warming on Venus. The planet is so hot due to intense atmospheric pressure.
author: Steve Smith

text:
¬†@Steve Smith¬† That thick atmosphere is still 96% CO2 so that is the cause of the density. That's just me arguing semantics though. SO2 (sulfur dioxide) and H2So4 (sulfuric acid) are the major causes of IR absorption on Venus.


For earth in the past the temperature change was primarily caused by changes in the earth orbit. The lag is because CO2 is both a cause and effect of warming and other factors. For times when the earth was cold and had high CO2 levels you have to ask can the CO2 offset the orbital  or other effect? Just because it was present in high levels during a time of glacial maximum does not mean it isn't a factor in temperature. Again you have to ask was there something that could offset its effect.


Today CO2 is not lagging temperature change and the CO2 levels are not naturally rising if you look at the rates we see today. This is the human factor.  I would like to see where the 0.01% human influence comes from and what all was factored in to come to that conclusion. It sounds like its a measure of hundreds or thousands of years to marginalize the current human influence. Would have to see the data to know for sure though. Like saying I have 100% greater income today or I have 0.01% greater income. Both can be true depending on the time frame you are looking at.


Saying we don't have control over weather is not the same as saying we have no affect.
author: DriveJapan

text: ¬†@DriveJapan¬† I never said CO2 wasn't a factor. I contend it is not a DRIVING factor. There is no evidence for that. If so, please present it. No one has modeled the climate properly. The climate includes all living organisms on the planet and is a wildly chaotic system. So to assert with certainty that one element of that system is the reason for climate change seems absurd.
author: Steve Smith

text:
¬†@Steve Smith¬† Actually, we've raised global CO2 levels from 280 to 415, a roughly 48% increase. The amount we produce knocks the whole natural carbon balance out of whack (between that the Earth releases and that which it stores).  
"Just in the last 600 million years, the Earth has seen CO2 levels 20x what they are today, during glacial periods no less." True, but irrelevant: We weren't here then, and until we started burning fossil fuels, global CO2 levels had been 300 or lower for the last 800,000 years... and THOSE are the CO2 levels that life on Earth is adapted to.  
Take care.

text:
Bill Nye is reporting INCORRECT or INCOMPLETE FACTS, without ever citing a source or a study. Definitely not how science communication should be done. 
Here are three examples:


1) At 0:24 he shows a graph of the temperature increase from 1880, without bothering to note that around 1850 ended a natural COOLING period know as the Little Ice Age, after which obviously temperatures have risen again. If you look at the COMPLETE graph (e.g. starting from year 1000) you can see the bigger picture.
2)The 97% consensus from minute 0:41 comes from the famous study of Cook et al from 2013, which was conducted with deplorable methodology, basically ignoring all the dissensus (I could elaborate on that but you can search yourselves)
3)The graph at 1:29 forgot to include water vapour which is by far the most abundant greenhouse gas in the atmosphere (here I am just talking about the fact that he forgot to mention its mere presence).


The things I have written are of course debatable, as science should be. What science shouldn't be, is a bunch of graphs containing decontextualized and partial information in order to support your thesis.

text:
¬†@Mark s¬† More CO2 DOES make plants grow faster in a greenhouse in the short run, but on a global level it has catastrophic long-term ripple effects--including for crops and forests and the oceans. As I taught one of my classes recently, the long-term harmful effects of rapidly adding much  more CO2 include global warming of the land, atmosphere, and especially oceans; rapid and accelerating melting of the Earth‚Äôs ice sheets and glaciers, rising sea levels (very slow at first but increasingly catastrophic), growing shortages of freshwater for drinking and irrigation affecting billions of people, more intense droughts, floods, and wildfires; and more air pollution and related human health problems due to more intense forest fires.  

The overly-optimistic folks who claim that global greening from more CO2 apparently don‚Äôt know that with the greening, weeds tend to really benefit, and with the warming you get more harm to crops and forests from insects, fungi, and disease; grain crops have already lost 5-8% or more of key nutrients due to more CO2 and will continue to lose more, and the amount of sugars in grain crops will continue to rise. Lower nutrient content and higher sugar content in our foods just feeds the crisis of obesity and related diseases, driving up health care costs further. Also, more CO2 means plants will grow thicker leaves and need more water due to increased CO2 (this will intensify water shortages as 70-80% of freshwater is used for agriculture/food production). The more intense droughts and floods creates problems for many farmers, and the range where certain crops can be grown efficiently has moved towards the poles by 100 miles or more already: Unfortunately, there is less land near the poles than in the fatter middle of the Earth, and the land up there often hasn‚Äôt had time or opportunity (permafrost) to develop really rich topsoil. Thus, while more CO2 can increase crop growth at first, as warming and all the other ripple effects kick in, crops get more stressed and struggle: Thus, a recent study expects 60% of the global wheat crop to be threatened by 2100. 

More CO2 and the warming it causes also means the spread of human disease as the ‚Äútropics‚Äù and its mosquito-borne diseases expand by 30 miles a decade, while melting permafrost has unleased other diseases long-frozen in the ice (e.g., anthrax). 

Then there‚Äôs the warming-caused mass die-offs of coral reefs and the fish and other aquatic life that depend on them, the increasing drying of America from west to east, the slowing of ocean currents with ripple effects for climate (already beginning) and increasing the size of dead zones in the ocean, the collapse of ecosystems on land (permafrost region, drying of the Amazon) and sea (decline/collapse of coral reefs and fish populations, polar ecosystem heading for collapse as ‚Äúcold-enough‚Äù areas disappear), sea snails at the bottom of the food chain having their shells dissolve at much higher rates because of the more acidic oceans, other shellfish having a harder time building shells, and thus being 30-50% smaller than normal), almost all green sea turtles are now being born female (because gender is regulated by the temperature of the sand at that time of year). 

More CO2 rapid die-offs of species related to the above‚Äîincluding the disappearance of 40% of the plankton population since the 1950s, increasing crop failures due to the above, increasingly-worsening refugees crises due to the above, increasingly staggering mitigation and repair costs due to the above, and increasing political and social instability and violence and resource conflicts/wars (already happening) due to all of the above. The chain reactions are vastly worse than you have ever been told‚Äîtruly catastrophic in the long run, leading (if we don‚Äôt take rapid action) to the collapse of ecosystems, our food supply, and our civilization and population. I don‚Äôt know, but I do know that very few scientists know all of these destructively cascading ripple effects because most don‚Äôt read much outside of their specialty. P.S. I didn‚Äôt even include all of those ripple effects.

So, if you are watching videos and reading on websites that ‚ÄúHey, more CO2 is great‚Äîit‚Äôs plant food,‚Äù I want to know why aren‚Äôt these folks aren‚Äôt telling you the WHOLE story? Why are they only telling you about 1% of the changes rapidly increasing CO2 levels will cause, and leaving out the other 99%.  Is it because they don‚Äôt know the whole story? That may be  understandable‚ÄîI only know all this because I‚Äôve been researching for more than 10 years on a book about what we need to do to protect and heal society and the planet. However, some of these harms have been well-publicized, so if these people are scientifically literate, they should know about them. Another possibility regarding some of the site/sources that gleefully declare ‚ÄúCO2 is plant food!‚Äù is that they are PAID to spread propaganda like pretending more CO2 is all good news. After all, the fossil fuels companies have been spending $200 million or more a year to spread propaganda to confuse people, and they may have funded the folks that provided some of the information you heard. 

Take care.
author: Karl Wheatley

author: DriveJapan

text:
¬†@DriveJapan¬† Of course. What I personally think of the matter, i.e. if the observed temperature increase in the last decades is attributable to human activity, is irrelevant. Even if it were relevant to the present discussion, it would be an uninformed opinion as I am not a climate scientist (I am quite accustomed to scientific research and methodology though).

Even if shared Bill's conclusions about the topic (which I may), I would still criticize the method by which he arrives to those conclusions, that is by cherry picking the information that confirms them. Take the world temperature graph he shows as an example. It gives the strong impression of a sudden and unprecedented temperature increase in the last two centuries. Obviously, once put in the broader context of, say, the temperature variations of the last 1000 years, it would be evident that he starts showing his graph from a period in which temperatures were at a local minimum, so that they increase after that. Of course this does not imply that the conclusions are wrong, but only that the data he shows is not at all evidence for them.

text:
Unique philosophical perspective on Anthropogenic Climate Change 


I think that human-induced climate catastrophe and this mass extinction Era-changing event is expected, correct and it couldn‚Äôt be more appropriate for the story of this planet.  Based on the unavoidable, existential, and cycled principles of  development, decay, renovation, and change. It won‚Äôt be stopped, it cant be stopped, and it shouldn‚Äôt be ordained too. The collapse of the Cenozoic era will be a bullet-fast death in the geological timescale, like a comet impact. A Shakespearean natural story of a Geologic Era structurally driven towards the ultimate specialization of complex mammalian life. Culminating in the circumstantial but inevitable evolution of a mammalian species that achieved animal sentience and that in an split of a second developed itself beyond life‚Äôs wildest dreams, covering the earth with its technological hive structures that consumed the planet‚Äôs biosphere like a fungal parasitic entity multiplying out of control, killing itself (as a supermassive social structure) and wiping most species from existence. A story of aspiration and the beautiful cost of arrogance, that reached far enough to touch godhood but fell like the melted wings of Icarus, taking the whole ecosphere structure down with it in a spectacular extinction event. We are a territorial and tribe structures species with decentralized social structures that are unavoidably in competition with each other, as  defined by the characteristics our species we are incapable of pulling off the simultaneous cohesive global effort to correct climate change. Thinking that we can is wishful thinking and it foolishly ignores the primal fundamental characteristics that define us as a species. The sixth extinction will be the womb upon which the new geologic era of life will be born. Life will recover and renovate its evolutionary focus in another direction. Just like the apocalyptic end of the Mesozoic and the extinction of the dinosaurs was necessary to give way to the Cenozoic era of  mammals and to us, and we are its crescendo and ultimate conclusion. Anthropogenic Climate Change as a cataclysmically-fast planet deteriorating  event is the most fitting end for us and our evolutive era. It might be ugly or painful for our own animalistic interpretation, which is dominated by emotions and instincts. And it might be tragic and sad for other species. But nature is not empathic, it never has been.  So Climate Change  isn‚Äôt bad or good, it just is. It fits wondrously with the structures of existence. Atoms fuse and decay, organism are born develop die and decompose, humans grow in their youth, develop into old age and die. All societies and empires have risen, reached a zenith, declined and fallen, new societies borrow from the ashes of old ones. Species go extinct and evolve into new creations. In a billion years this planet will return to the primal lifeless heat from which it came. Our star will expand and explode our solar system will die, new solar systems will be created with material from ours within them. The universe born with a bang will continue to expand and change, decay and simplify its structures and darken until in an unimaginable scale of time the laws of physics themselves fade and cease to exist. These cycles and  structured paths of development on all scales are the defining condition of spacetime existence  and are therefore unavoidable, it is futile to resist them, and it‚Äôs okay to face and accept them.

text:
"I need evidence before Bill will panic me!" Here's part 2
As I taught one of my classes recently, the long-term harmful effects of rapidly adding much  more CO2 include global warming of the land, atmosphere, and especially oceans; rapid and accelerating melting of the Earth‚Äôs ice sheets and glaciers, rising sea levels (very slow at first but increasingly catastrophic), growing shortages of freshwater for drinking and irrigation affecting billions of people, more intense droughts, floods, and wildfires; and more air pollution and related human health problems due to more intense forest fires.  

The overly-optimistic folks who claim that global greening from more CO2 apparently don‚Äôt know that with the greening, weeds tend to really benefit, and with the warming you get more harm to crops and forests from insects, fungi, and disease; grain crops have already lost 5-8% or more of key nutrients due to more CO2 and will continue to lose more, and the amount of sugars in grain crops will continue to rise. Lower nutrient content and higher sugar content in our foods just feeds the crisis of obesity and related diseases, driving up health care costs further. Also, more CO2 means plants will grow thicker leaves and need more water due to increased CO2 (this will intensify water shortages as 70-80% of freshwater is used for agriculture/food production). The more intense droughts and floods creates problems for many farmers, and the range where certain crops can be grown efficiently has moved towards the poles by 100 miles or more already: Unfortunately, there is less land near the poles than in the fatter middle of the Earth, and the land up there often hasn‚Äôt had time or opportunity (permafrost) to develop really rich topsoil. Thus, while more CO2 can increase crop growth at first, as warming and all the other ripple effects kick in, crops get more stressed and struggle: Thus, a recent study expects 60% of the global wheat crop to be threatened by 2100. 

More CO2 and the warming it causes also means the spread of human disease as the ‚Äútropics‚Äù and its mosquito-borne diseases expand by 30 miles a decade, while melting permafrost has unleased other diseases long-frozen in the ice (e.g., anthrax). 

Then there‚Äôs the warming-caused mass die-offs of coral reefs and the fish and other aquatic life that depend on them, the increasing drying of America from west to east, the slowing of ocean currents with ripple effects for climate (already beginning) and increasing the size of dead zones in the ocean, the collapse of ecosystems on land (permafrost region, drying of the Amazon) and sea (decline/collapse of coral reefs and fish populations, polar ecosystem heading for collapse as ‚Äúcold-enough‚Äù areas disappear), sea snails at the bottom of the food chain having their shells dissolve at much higher rates because of the more acidic oceans, other shellfish having a harder time building shells, and thus being 30-50% smaller than normal), almost all green sea turtles are now being born female (because gender is regulated by the temperature of the sand at that time of year). 

More CO2 rapid die-offs of species related to the above‚Äîincluding the disappearance of 40% of the plankton population since the 1950s, increasing crop failures due to the above, increasingly-worsening refugees crises due to the above, increasingly staggering mitigation and repair costs due to the above, and increasing political and social instability and violence and resource conflicts/wars (already happening) due to all of the above. The chain reactions are vastly worse than you have ever been told‚Äîtruly catastrophic in the long run, leading (if we don‚Äôt take rapid action) to the collapse of ecosystems, our food supply, and our civilization and population. I don‚Äôt know, but I do know that very few scientists know all of these destructively cascading ripple effects because most don‚Äôt read much outside of their specialty. P.S. I didn‚Äôt even include all of those ripple effects.

So, if you are watching videos and reading on websites that ‚ÄúHey, more CO2 is great‚Äîit‚Äôs plant food,‚Äù I want to know why aren‚Äôt these folks aren‚Äôt telling you the WHOLE story? Why are they only telling you about 1% of the changes rapidly increasing CO2 levels will cause, and leaving out the other 99%.  Is it because they don‚Äôt know the whole story? That may be  understandable‚ÄîI only know all this because I‚Äôve been researching for more than 10 years on a book about what we need to do to protect and heal society and the planet. However, some of these harms have been well-publicized, so if these people are scientifically literate, they should know about them. Another possibility regarding some of the site/sources that gleefully declare ‚ÄúCO2 is plant food!‚Äù is that they are PAID to spread propaganda like pretending more CO2 is all good news. After all, the fossil fuels companies have been spending $200 million or more a year to spread propaganda to confuse people, and they may have funded the folks that provided some of the information you heard. 

Take care.

text: Something that used to confuse me: Archimedes principle states that an object immersed in a fluid is buoyed up by a force equal to the weight of the fluid it displaces, making so that the melting of ice in water couldn‚Äôt possibly raise the sea levels, because the volume would stay the same. The thing is that glacier ice is mostly made of fresh water, inferior in density to saltwater and thus any body of freshwater occupies a bigger volume than a body of salt water of the same mass. That means that when a glacier melts, it contributes to a greater volume of melt water than it originally displaced (not by much but it remains alarming)

Published reviews of the scientific literature by M√∂rner and Etiope (2002) and Kerrick (2001) report a range of emission of 65 to 319 million tonnes of CO2 per year. text:
The earth's temperature changes through geologic history are not slight. They range from extremes of cold and hot, called glacial and interglacial periods. From glacial period to glacial period it's about 100,000 years. We are out of an ice age and rising up the slope to the max interglacial period. This means high temperatures. I also want to clarify we also have not reached the highest temp on earth, just highest recorded temp. All this being said I dont necessarily want to get to that extreme heat faster than necessary. 

Edit: Also it would be ignorant to think that such a large organism on the planet (humans) would not have an impact on the planet with or with out the industrial revolution. We are absolutely increasing temp with our ridiculous natural resource uses.

text:
Look I'm willing to accept that climate change is a thing but saying 97% of climate scientists agree about something doesn't mean much and is certainly not scientific. More extreme weather conditions does not suggest that climate change exists. It COULD be one factor but there's no hard evidence presented here. I'm looking for hard scientific evidence and the first 3 youtube videos that come up when you search "Climate change evidence" are speculative and do not give any evidence.¬†Saying "the main take away is that its real" hugely undermines your argument because your asking people to accept a message without understanding or evidence. How is that scientific? Its the definition of dogma.

If anyone has any links to scientific papers or informative videos that aren't speculative and provide more than circumstantial evidence please feel free to share. I'm not a climate change denier because i don't know enough to say whether it is or not but I certainly will not be convinced by an argument that is emotive or speculative at best. I'm just a guy who is seeking the truth.

text:
Buzzkill i think its great that you would like to actually learn about the subject hollistically, as opposed to getting involved in the hysteria!
I would recommend a video called 'Conversations on Climate Change' uploaded by a channel called 'spilmanlaw'. It is a debate which discusses the extent of which human-caused carbon emissions  affect the climate. The panel involves 4 speakers. 2 of them believe that human activity is what is causes the globe to be warming at an alarming rate, and the other 2 believe that the nature plays a big part in the change in climate, and the globe is most likely not warming rapidly to dangerous levels.
Some of the speakers in this debate do use dogma to convince the audience of their point, but others actually use evidence to help you understand the nuances of the issue.
I really do recommend you watch the video in its entirity, not just to learn the nitty gritty details through evidence, but to also see the obsurdity involved in the arguments made. Peace fellow truth seeker!

text:
Whilst videos like are very informative and great to watch, scare mongering won‚Äôt change people‚Äôs behaviour. We need to find a way to really make people care about the issue enough that the leaders of our world have a political and economic incentive actually bring about change. Whilst in every one of these types of videos there‚Äôs always a bit at the end telling us how we can ‚Äúbe part of the solution‚Äù, people either can‚Äôt bothered because it doesn‚Äôt feel like it directly affects them or it's too financially infeasible for them to make a lot those changes. How can we use less plastic if the cheap supermarkets people rely on package everything in plastic, how can we recycle properly if the local council doesn't provide sufficient recycling services, people can‚Äôt use renewable energy providers because it‚Äôs too expensive etc...
I appreciate this sounds like a negative view, because in reality there is always something small we can do, but not everyone has been educated about it, these videos are watched by people like myself who already understand agree with the video before even clicking on it.

text:
GLOBAL WARMING
For several years the amount of pollution and Co2 being put into the air is increasing everyday. This creates global warming. Global warming causes wildfires, water rises, and an increase of heat. It is our fault for fueling this with pollution, deforestation, and our lack of trying to change the situation. Global warming has significant effects on the health of the planet and us as a species.

To start this off, forests are affected by global warming in reason of more pollution, means more heat from global warming, meaning less rain, equalling to dry forests waiting for destruction. In an article called ‚ÄúIs Global Warming Fueling Increased Wildfire Risks?‚Äù it states ‚ÄúAs the climate warms, moisture and precipitation levels are changing, with wet areas becoming wetter and dry areas becoming direr They also said ‚Äú...hot, dry conditions also increase the likelihood that, once wildfires are started by lightning strikes or human error, they will be more intense and long-burning.‚Äù. This shows how global warming sets up forests like matches ready to be ignited by us, or naturally.This shows that global warming is causing dryness in the air, and that is a key element to fire. To add on, deforestation and wildfires means less trees to balance Co2 for less global warming, and wildfires are mostly caused naturally or by us. 

 Not only that but also, due to global warming the polar ice caps are melting and causing waters to rise and flood areas. In an article called ‚ÄúAre the Effects of Global Warming Really That Bad?‚Äù states ‚ÄúThe polar regions are particularly vulnerable to a warming atmosphere‚Äù...‚ÄùThis not only has grave consequences for the regions, people, wildlife, and plants; its most serious impact may be on rising sea levels. By 2100, it‚Äôs estimated our oceans will be one to four feet higher, threatening coastal systems and low-lying areas,‚Äù This shows that hat is an enemy to ice. The higher we let global warming to do this, beaches will overflow land area causing people to go the hills andhigher land. To add on, when the water rises, we have less land to live on like places in California, San Francisco, Japan or ‚Äúother close to the beach‚Äù areas.

 Although this may be true, others think global warming is a myth or a debatable subject not yet proved. To a website called ‚Äúfriends of science‚Äù it states ‚ÄúCarbon dioxide levels have indeed changed for various reasons, humans and otherwise, just as they thought geological time...However, there is no proof that Co2 is the main driver of global warming.‚Äù They also said ‚ÄúThere is no scientific evidence whatsoever that supports such claims on a global scale. Regional variations may occur.‚Äù This shows how people may have thought global warming isn‚Äôt real, and maybe said we ‚Äúdon‚Äôt have evidence‚Äù because people haven‚Äôt seen real problems yet. These people believe it‚Äôs not global, as in some places because they think its in some places instead of a global scale, however if they keep believing that until something bad happens it might be too late to fix this.
 
The increased activity on pollution being put into the air causes disasters such as wildfires, water rises and heat. We fuel this with deforestation, smoking and pollution. Global warming is on of our significant effects in health of us and our planet.

text:
Sea level changes over relatively recent geologic and human history demonstrate that alarmist claims do not withstand scrutiny. Sea levels rose significantly after the last ice age, fell during the Little Ice Age, and have been rising again since the LIA ended around 1850. In fact, Roman Empire and Medieval port cities are now miles from the Mediterranean, because sea levels actually fell during the Little Ice Age.

During the deepest part of the last ice age, known as the Wisconsin, sea levels were about 400 feet lower than at present. As Earth emerged from the Wisconsin some 18,000 years ago and the massive ice sheets started to melt, sea levels began rising. Rapid sea level rise during the ‚Äúmeltwater pulse phase,‚Äù about 15,000 years ago, was roughly five meters (16 feet) per century ‚Äì but then slowed significantly since the Holocene Climate Optimum, about 8,000 years ago.

text:
CO2 is naturally taken out of the atmosphere slowly (much more slowly than we add it) (as long as we don't destroy too many forests), so if we stopped adding CO2 (almost) completely, temperatures would continue increasing for some time, but eventually CO2 levels would reduce, then temperatures would drop slowly.
We can increase the rate CO2 is taken out of the atmosphere by planting plants, especially trees.

text:
Much of recent global warming has been fabricated by climate scientists¬†to make it look more frightening, a¬†study¬†has found.

The peer-reviewed study by two scientists and a¬†veteran statistician¬†looked at the¬†global average temperature datasets (GAST) which are used by climate alarmists to argue that recent years have been ‚Äúthe hottest evah‚Äù and that the warming of the last 120 years has been dramatic and unprecedented.

What they found is that these readings are ‚Äútotally inconsistent with published and credible U.S. and other temperature data.‚Äù

That is, the adjusted data used by alarmist organizations like NASA, NOAA, and the UK Met Office¬†differs so markedly from the original raw data that it cannot be trusted.

text:
A sizable piece of the Antarctic Ice Shelf (50Km X 100Km) is about to break away and drift off. Ah Global Warming you say, but I was listening to David Vaughan (Director of Science, British Antarctic Survey) being interviewed on BBC world service's Science In Action. 

There is a research station on the ice shelf called Halley VI which they are/have moved so that it doesn't float away. Dr Vaughan has this responsibility! 

But when asked if this should be taken as another signal of climate change he said it was probably a mistake to do so. I was rather stunned at what he said which is this: "AT HALLEY WE HAVE MEASURED THE TEMPERATURES FOR 50 YEARS. WE HAVE NOT SEEN ANY EVIDENCE OF CLIMATE CHANGE IN THIS AREA" he went on to say this in contrast to the Arctic Peninsula (other end of the world) which has demonstrated recent rapid warming.

My point is this: The more the global warming believers say the evidence is irrefutable, and all one way, the more the doubters will point out that this is patently not true. And so each polarized camp becomes more, and more firmly entrenched.

With systems as complex as world climate, and with the massive quantities of data we are collecting on these systems, you can ALWAYS find evidence to support your own particular political/ philosophical/ religious/ economic/ scientific persecutive. This is a problem.

If we are going to find a solution all entrenched camps need to look seriously at the arguments of their opponents, rather than just shouting abuse and slander at them. And as well all sides need to examine there own arguments to make sure they are really solid, and not just empty propaganda.

text: Please don't troll this question as it is being asked in a serious way. There have been ice ages in the earths 4.6 billion year existence. Then the earth froze, and then it melted. This all happened before humans existed. Currently our earth has fair weather with blue skies and normal sea levels. I can assume that it will not be like this forever. I like to look at the facts and I am not judging people's opinion, but I have a hard time trusting someone who can't tell me what the weather will be in 3 weeks, let alone tell me that the earth's gradual rise in temperature is a serious and bad thing. As I am writing this comment, the sun can produce a giant heat wave and raise the temperature of the earth in drastic levels. In its Fifth Assessment Report, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a group of 1,300 independent scientific experts from countries all over the world under the auspices of the United Nations, concluded there's a more than 95 percent probability that human activities over the past 50 years have warmed our planet.

The industrial activities that our modern civilization depends upon have raised atmospheric carbon dioxide levels from 280 parts per million to 400 parts per million in the last 150 years. The panel also concluded there's a better than 95 percent probability that human-produced greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide have caused much of the observed increase in Earth's temperatures over the past 50 years.

text:
How to explain Climate Change in simple terms that defeat denier's argument that since Carbon dioxide is necessary for Earth's systems to function normally, it is not a thing: 

Climate change is basically Earth's diabetes. 
While yes, Carbon dioxide (sugar) is necessary for its normal functions, too much of it (Carbon dioxide emissions) causes an imbalance that results in its systems to function improperly; resulting in the phenomenon known as Climate Change (diabetes).If nothing is done to fix this imbalance, then you run the risk of this condition (Climate Change/ diabetes) becoming permanent.

That is basically Climate change in a nutshell.

CO2 is what plants breathe. Greenhouses on farms are pumped full of CO2 because it makes the crops grow faster, bigger, and with more nutrients. Corn has been hitting all time highs for yields for the last 5 years according to NOAA's raw data sets. When we believe the first explosion of life happened on Earth there was over 7000ppm CO2 in the atmosphere. Today we are around 400. Almost 20 times less. More CO2 means more oxygen which means more thriving life and more plants. That is a real snowball affect, unlike the "greenhouse affect." It is estimated by some scientists such as Dr. Patrick Moore that if we go below 150ppm atmospheric CO2 concentration, then all plant life will be unable to survive. We hit the lowest that we ever have in recent history, (past 500 years) and we are still on the extremely low end for atmospheric CO2 concentration. There is no downside to atmospheric CO2. In fact it is what keeps all life on Earth alive. And fossil fuels keep all of us alive when it gets too hot or too cold outside. It is what allows us to live with luxuries in life instead of like cavemen. 

The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere is controlled by the temperature. Not the other way around. When your water soda or beer gets warmer, more CO2 bubbles form and rise to the surface and are released into the atmosphere. Antarctic ice core data shows that CO2 levels and temperature have been parallel for the past 450,000 years. But CO2 lags temperature by 800 years. This is because of how heat cycles in the ocean. CO2 has a greenhouse affect on 3 electromagnetic radiation wavelengths. Water vapor has a greenhouse affect on more than 50, including the 3 that CO2 also has a possible affect on. All of those 3 wavelengths are already being held in the atmosphere. More CO2 will have a practically unnoticeable affect, if any. 

NOAA and NASA's current graphs and published data sets go against their previous data and raw data sets. The difference between a raw data set and a published one is that the raw data set is the pure data. It has not been altered or changed at all. The newer published data sets have more than 50% of the raw data replaced with either algorithm generated data or simply human inputted numbers, and they show the opposite of what the raw data shows. Anyone who gets government funding or works for these groups that push the propaganda is not allowed to speak out against global warming or they will lose their funding and their job. If these so called "heretics" get fairly well known, then they get whole websites devoted just to slandering them.

None of the predictions of these "scientists" have come true, and anyone can take a look outside and see that these wild claims about "60% of wildlife has been killed since 1970" or "Snow will be a thing of the past by 2020" or "40% of greenland has melted in summer 2019" or "NYC will be underwater by 2014" are completely false. Anyone can go to a legitimate organisation such as the DMI (Danish Meteorological Institute) and look at real data that goes completely against what groups with corrupt management say. Or they can take a look at NOAA's maps and raw data sets. Alaska is not having record heat right now like the media are reporting. It was -65 degrees in some places in the past week. The forecasts are all available online.

Climate models from climate "scientists" have never been needed, because we have geologists and paleontologists. They know the history of the earth and have studied what happens during circumstances very similar to the current one today. We do not need these predictions, because we already have data that has fairly closely repeated itself, and laws based on that data. That is how you do science, data. You adjust theories to match the data. You do not adjust data to match your theories, that is not science, that is fraud. All of what I say has been preached by real scientists for decades, and the actual number of scientists that believe in global warming is around 3%. Not 97%. Go and check everything I have said at the sources I have cited. The official government sources that the global warming believers preach. The only difference is that I do not listen to their PR departments or management. I look at the data and the scientists who quietly do their job gathering it.

text:
! Here it is again by popular request;
Heat Waves: Dr. Judith Curry, Chair of the School of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences at the Georgia Institute of Technology offered Senate testimony on January 16, 2014. She showed an analysis of 982 stations from the U.S. Historical Climate Network for the 48 continental states with more than 80 years of record. The data show a strong peak of record maximum daily temperatures occurred in the 1930s, with no increasing trend in the post-WWII years when CO2 started its modern increase.
Of the 50 states, the number of state maximum record temperatures obtained from NOAA‚Äôs National Climate Data Center, by decade, shows that in the 1930s, 23 states set their all-time high temperatures, by far the largest number of such record highs. There has not been a single state record maximum set in the 21st Century.
Droughts: The most-often used indicator of drought is the Palmer Drought Severity Index. Curry‚Äôs testimony included a PDSI chart, showing the most severe droughts in the 102-year record 1910-2012, were in the 1930s and a lesser maximum in the 1950s. Data show no indication that drought severity has increased as CO2 has increased.
Floods: Dr. Roger Pielke, Jr., from the University of Colorado, testified to the Senate EPW Committee on July 18, 2013. With respect to floods, he provided data from the US Geological Survey, which show in the U.S., floods have not increased in frequency or intensity since at least 1950, and that flood losses, as a percentage of GDP have dropped by about 75% since 1940, based on data from NOAA‚Äôs Hydrologic Information Center.
Somerville says that increasing CO2 will harm plant productivity, but the opposite is true. First, realize that both plants and animals, including humans, are carbon-based life forms. With increasing CO2, there is an incredible array of beneficial effects spelled out in the book, The Many Benefits of Atmospheric CO2 Enrichment, by Craig Idso and Sherman Idso. The benefits include: increasing water-use efficiency; increasing biomass in roots, stems, flowers and nectar; larger seeds; avoiding human starvation and plant and animal extinctions; stimulating early plant growth; and resistance to plant diseases. The carbohydrates we consume when we eat are derived directly from CO2 in the atmosphere; carbohydrates are the source of the energy we need to survive and thrive

text:
Human activity--such as burning fossil fuels--causes more greenhouse gases to build up in the atmosphere. As the atmosphere "thickens" with more greenhouse gases, more heat is held in. Fossil fuels such as oil, coal and natural gas are high in carbon and, when burned, produce major amounts of carbon dioxide or CO2. A single gallon of gasoline, when burned, puts 19 pounds of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

The role of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) in warming the Earth's surface was first demonstrated by Swedish scientist Svante Arrhenius more than 100 years ago. Scientific data have since established that, for hundreds of thousands of years, changes in temperature have closely tracked with atmospheric CO2 concentrations. Since the Industrial Revolution, the burning of coal, oil and natural gas has emitted roughly 500 billion tons of CO2, about half of which remains in the atmosphere. This CO2 is the biggest factor responsible for recent warming trends.

An annual State of the Climate report has confirmed that 2015 surpassed 2014 as the warmest year on record since at least the mid-to-late 19th century.

Last year‚Äôs record heat resulted from a combination of long-term global warming and one of the strongest El Ni√±o experienced since at least 1950, according to the more than 450 scientists that contributed to the report. They found that most indicators of climate change continued to reflect trends consistent with a global warming.   

Notable findings from the report include:

Greenhouse gases were the highest on record. Major greenhouse gas concentrations, including carbon dioxide (CO2), methane and nitrous oxide, rose to new record high values during 2015. The 2015 average global CO2 concentration was 399.4 parts per million (ppm), an increase of 2.2 ppm compared with 2014.

Global surface temperature was the highest on record. Aided by the strong El Ni√±o, the 2015 annual global surface temperature was 0.76‚Äì0.83 degrees F (0.42¬∞‚Äì0.46¬∞C) above the 1981‚Äì2010 average, surpassing the previous record set in 2014.

Sea surface temperature was the highest on record. The globally averaged sea surface temperature was 0.59‚Äì0.70 degrees F (0.33¬∞‚Äì0.39¬∞C) above average, breaking the previous mark set in 2014.

Global upper ocean heat content highest on record. Upper ocean heat content exceeded the record set in 2014, reflecting the continuing accumulation of heat in the ocean‚Äôs top layers.  

Global sea level rose to a new record high in 2015. It measured about 2.75 inches (70 mm) higher than that observed in 1993, when satellite record-keeping for global sea level rise began.

Tropical cyclones were well above average, overall. There were 101 tropical cyclones total across all ocean basins in 2015, well above the 1981-2010 average of 82 storms. The eastern/central Pacific had 26 named storms, the most since 1992. The North Atlantic, in contrast, had fewer storms than most years during the last two decades.

The Arctic continued to warm; sea ice extent remained low. The Arctic land surface temperature in 2015 was 2.2 degrees F (1.2¬∞C) above the 1981-2010 average, tying 2007 and 2011 as the highest on record. The maximum Arctic sea ice extent reached in February 2015 was the smallest in the 37-year satellite record, while the minimum sea ice extent that September was the fourth lowest on record.

author: Rambo

text:
¬†@Rambo¬† 
'Hard data'? But who is to make sense of it? If I may, that is the core thing that makes these type of subjects difficult and worthy of greater respect. Note I am not making the argument of 'equal evidence, different interpretation' but that quite simply, me lacking any knowledge of climatology means I won't see so much of the evidence.

So, no, I went just play around with numbers to claim that since human net contribution to carbon dioxide is little, does it mean the impact is little. Because for one, the argument is that the system is not balanced with the other carbon in the carbon cycle and there is things with feedback loops. See, it's not data I'm worried about-I'm worried about incredulity. Do I fully understand this? No. Perhaps I will get around to it, I did do a bit of digging into the mechanisms and the actual consensus studies but at the moment I am focused on other topics.

It's not up to me or you to use our ignorant judgement. If this comes off as highly elitist, it is probably because it is.
author: Sarah Bell

text:
¬†@Sarah Bell¬† You're right only people who have deep knowledge in a topic should interpret the data. So simply listen to qualified people with counter arguments. I would suggest starting with Richard Lindzen and William Happer videos. 


Just because everyone used to believe the earth was flat didn't make it true.
author: Rambo

text:
¬†@Rambo¬† 
I don't care about videos. That is not how scientific research is done. The state of science so far as we look into the journals appears to agree in large part on the side of climate change.


Finally, Richard Lindzen is a meterologist and William Happer is a physicist. And that being said, doing some ground level research, it would appear his alternative 'iris effect' explanation has been under severe criticism and has not found these types of papers being published in journals.


He can blame group think all he wants but from my point of view, where I have no knowledge of climatology, I quite simply have to go with what the science says.

text: @Ethan Trenaman, making arguments is an essential part of reasoning but to make your arguments stronger, you should realize that in critical reasoning there is something called an "is-ought fallacy" that states that just because something is, doesn't mean that that's how it ought to be. This includes making an argument that we have canines and that our ancestors ate meat, so therefore we should eat meat. Just because it is a fact that our ancestors ate meat and we have canines, doesn't mean that it ought to be that way when we possess the means and ability to make more moral decisions.

"Electronics For Fun I'm not sure where the logic is here. The key takeaway is that humans are eating too much meat.
