"we need both meat and vegetation to properly sustain ourselves." so how did you interpret that as we need to eat more meat? 

"Also you can't compare what a lion eats to a cheeseburger. Mass produced meat is incredibly bad for you and humans were never designed to eat preservatives and artificial growth hormones and whatever other junk goes into slaughterhouse animals." well yeah if you eat "cheeseburgers" from McDonalds then that is true, but if you eat a cheeseburger made from real meat then it's no different than eating a cow. all you're doing is adding more to it like wheat, ketchup, lettuce, and tomato. 

"Mass produced meat is incredibly bad for you and humans were never designed to eat preservatives and artificial growth hormones and whatever other junk goes into slaughterhouse animals." then go eat an organic grass fed meat, they don't use any of that junk in the meat. they raise the cows normally and then when they get old enough they turn them into burgers and steaks. 

"We are naturally omnivores yes, but what we eat is anything but natural. See the problem?" why does it have to be natural? when you live in a society there is nothing "natural" about what humans do. our food, our technology, or life styles. we are the only animals on this planet that live this way. don't think that your vegetables are safe to eat either, GMOs, pesticides, and bad water supply. our crops are just as bad as our meat, you're not safe just sticking to one of them because they are both bad. but if you're going to eat junk then you might as well balance out your junk.

text:
I find it fascinating how right-wing fanboys, many of which have a high school diploma-at best, can also be so knowledgeable when it comes to Earth and climate change. Despite the testimony of 97% of scientists who have been studying this stuff for many years, you and many others, like yourself, hold firm in your expert knowledge that those 97% are "up to something." 

Regardless of your position on climate change, etc., the fact is eventually we will run out of fossil fuels. Sure, we have enough to last for a little while (less than you think)..but, even so, then what? 

--It should be appealing to "fiscal" conservatives because: switching to  alternative energy earlier will be less costly in the long run. Consistent change, which takes place now, means less negative impact on the economy, as a result. 

--It should be appealing to "Libertarians," because: Supporting minimal government measures today is better than dealing with significant government intervention down the road. Governments will always become more active and intrusive during disasters, and the longer we wait: the more it will cost, the more drastic the impact, and more intrusive government policies will be to combat climate change. This should be relevant to libertarians since their only focus seems to be on the government leaving them alone. 

--It should be appealing to all right-wingers, because: You still get to keep your guns and fuck your sisters.

text:
I'm Australian, so I can tell you why¬†we took away the carbon tax.¬† It was pure politics of big coal.¬† The progressive Labour¬†party, introduced the law,¬† but then lost the next election from in-fighting.¬†
Anyone from the conservative party could have won that election, which they did and¬†the¬†new prime minister, Abbot was a well known climate change denier (and my local rep, I saw him a few times¬†down the beach).¬†¬† 
Coal is BIG business here, so any direct¬†tax on it was not going to last once conservatives were in.
The promise was that once the carbon tax was taken away, our power bills would go down.¬† they have not, in fact they have continued to go up at a faster rate than before.¬† 
The conservatives now have a new leader Turnbull, (who Trump insulted last week), he's more pragmatic & is looking to introduce a carbon trading scheme, which will have a similar effect as a carbon tax, just won't be called a tax.
So the carbon tax was got rid of for political reasons.
I suspect these facts do not assist you in making your point.
But looking at the conversation so far, facts are not your strong suit.

text: Eating red meat specifically.  Most of the rainforests are cut down in order to make room for cattle grazing, however the rainforests are massive carbon sinks.  Cows actually emit a massive amount of methane, which traps 100 times more heat in the atmosphere than carbon dioxide.  So basically, by continuing to eat cow meat, we perpetuate the problem.  The cows create methane, which traps heat, and because we have less rainforest due to cow farm expansion, the carbon dioxide produced from other human sources cannot be scrubbed by the rainforest.

text:
Oct 2016334    
    
   
   
    
    
    SIGN UP FOR OUR NEWSLETTERJames Lovelock, inventor of Gaia Theory and godfather of the modern environmental¬†movement, has finally renounced the green religion.
Climate alarmism, he says, is not ‚Äúremotely scientific‚Äù; one volcano 
could make more difference to global warming than humans ever could; the
 computer models are ‚Äúunreliable‚Äù; greens have behaved ‚Äúdeplorably‚Äù; and
 anyone who tries to ‚Äúpredict more than five to ten years is a bit of an
 idiot.‚Äù
Though this is not the first time Lovelock has rowed back on his 
earlier climate catastrophism ‚Äì in 2012 he was already admitting ‚ÄúI made a mistake‚Äù ‚Äì it‚Äôs his most emphatic rejection yet of the green litany.
Lovelock, 97, ascribes the dramatic change in his once fervently alarmist beliefs¬†to the fact that he has ‚Äúgrown up.‚Äù
Only ten¬†years ago ‚Äì when the inventor, scientist and 
environmentalist was a mere spring chicken of 87 ‚Äì Lovelock¬†argued in 
his book The Revenge of Gaia¬†that mankind was¬†doomed.
Because of global warming, he predicted, ‚Äúbillions will die‚Äù and the 
few survivors would have to retreat to the Arctic which would be one of 
the few habitable places left on earth.
But now he admits to being ‚Äúlaid back about climate change.‚Äù




‚ÄúCO2 is going up, but nowhere near as fast as they 
thought it would. The computer models just weren‚Äôt reliable. In fact I‚Äôm
 not sure the whole thing isn‚Äôt crazy, this climate change. You‚Äôve only 
got to look at Singapore. It‚Äôs two-and-a-half times higher than the 
worst-case scenario for climate change, and it‚Äôs one of the most 
desirable cities in the world to live in.‚Äù
Besides, he says, nature is more powerful than the computer models:
It‚Äôs only got to take one sizable volcano to erupt and all the models, everything else, is right off the board.
Lovelock was speaking in an interview with the fervently alarmist 
Guardian whose interviewer Decca Aitkenhead was naturally somewhat taken
 aback by his views which she ascribed in part to his temperament as an 
‚Äúincorrigible subversive.‚Äù
But Lovelock himself insists that it is simply a question of looking at the evidence.
One experience that has sharply concentrated his thoughts is the cost
 of heating his home, an old mill in Devon. When the heating bills rose 
to ¬£6,000 for just six months, he realised that he would have to 
downsize and has now moved to a smaller cottage¬†on¬†Chesil Beach in 
Dorset. This claim has brought him into conflict with another green 
guru, the chunky knit Guardianista George Monbiot.
‚ÄúI remember George Monbiot took me up on it
 and wrote that it was impossible, that I had to be lying. But I wasn‚Äôt 
lying, I‚Äôve got the figures.‚Äù Monbiot doesn‚Äôt quite accuse him of lying,
 in fairness; just of ‚Äútalking rubbish‚Äù and ‚Äúmaking wild statements‚Äù. In
 any case, he says that in the US he found he could heat a house for six
 months, in temperatures of -20C (-4F), for just ¬£60. As a result, he 
has withering contempt for environmentalists‚Äô opposition to fracking. 
‚ÄúYou see, gas in America is incredibly cheap, because of fracking,‚Äù he 
says. But what about the risk of triggering earthquakes? He rolls his 
eyes.
‚ÄúSure enough, that‚Äôs true, there will be an increase. But they‚Äôre 
tiny little tremors, they would be imperceptible. The only trouble is 
that you can detect them. The curse of my life has been that I‚Äôve spent a
 lot of time inventing devices that are exceedingly sensitive. And the 
moment somebody can detect something, they‚Äôre going to attach a number 
to it, and then they make a fuss about it.‚Äù He chuckles, then pauses. 
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not anti-green in the sense that I‚Äôm in favour of polluting the 
world with every damn thing we make. I think we‚Äôve got to be careful. 
But I‚Äôm afraid, human nature being what it is, the thing gets 
exaggerated out of all proportion, and the greens have behaved 
deplorably instead of being reasonably sensible.‚Äù
Besides Monbiot, Lovelock finds time for a little dig at yet another fervent green catastrophist the Prince of Wales:
He was once invited to Buckingham Palace, where he told 
Princess Anne: ‚ÄúYour brother nearly killed me.‚Äù Having read that Prince 
Charles had installed grass-burning boilers
 at Highgrove, Lovelock had tried one in his house. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs supposed to 
smoulder and keep the place warm; but it doesn‚Äôt, because it goes out, 
and clouds and clouds of smoke come out.‚Äù He giggles. ‚ÄúPrincess Anne 
thought this was hilariously funny.‚Äù
His heretical stance on nuclear energy too is likely to alienate many of his former admirers in the green movement:




Even more heretical than his enthusiasm for fracking is Lovelock‚Äôs passionate support for nuclear power.
 But, like fracking, he says, it offers only ‚Äúa stopgap‚Äù solution. 
‚ÄúBecause in the long term, they‚Äôll use up all the uranium.‚Äù How long 
would that take? He pauses to do some quick mental arithmetic, as 
casually as I might tot up how many pints of milk to grab from 
Sainsburys.
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs see ‚Ä¶ I think uranium that is affordable to extract would last
 about 50 years, something in that range. It might be 100. When you‚Äôve 
used all that up, you go to thorium, and that would last you three times
 as long as uranium ‚Äì so, shall we say, about 200 years?‚Äù The most 
sensible energy solution would be to cover 100 sq miles of the Sahara in
 solar panels. ‚ÄúIt would supply the whole of Europe with all the energy 
they needed,‚Äù but it won‚Äôt happen ‚Äúbecause it would be so easy for 
terrorists to go and bugger it up‚Äù. So for now, nuclear energy is the 
only viable option.
Not that any of this matters much anyway, Lovelock suggests, because 
by the end of the century robots will have taken over and they probably 
won‚Äôt find much use for us.
The implications for climate change are obvious. ‚ÄúThe 
world that they‚Äôre going to be comfortable in is wildly different from 
the one that we feel comfortable in. So once they really get 
established, they will ‚Äì with regret ‚Äì start losing organic life.‚Äù Will 
they care about rising temperatures? ‚ÄúThey won‚Äôt give a fourpenny fuck 
about the temperature, because to them the change will be slow, and they
 can stand quite a big change without any fuss. They could accommodate

text:
Nye is a hack and a fraud.  Nothing he said is accurate.  I challenge any green who thinks they know what they are talking about to a debate.  

Your hypothesis has 4 separate premises that all build on each other.
1.¬† The rate of warming is increasing (not that there is warming)
2.¬† Human co2 emissions are the cause
3.¬† It is severe and catastrophic
4.¬† Your plan of artificially inflating the price of energy around the world to reduce c02 emissions will be less catastrophic than adapting to it

So let's start with premise 1:¬† The rate of warming increased during the 20th century as opposed to the 19th century.
According to the only measurement that I can think of to test this theory, the tidal gauges, that has not been shown and infact the IPCC has reluctantly admitted that:
"No significant acceleration in the rate of sea level rise during the 20th century has been detected."
¬†https://www.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/tar/wg1/409.htm
The global sea level rise is  roughly 2mm per year and as far as we can tell that is the rate it has been rising since the end of the little ice age.  
http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/globalregional.htm

Besides the tidal gauges I don't know of any global measurements that go back into the pre-industrial age with any accuracy.
Global surface temperature was first measured (not estimated with a huge margin of error)  in 1978 by John Christy at UAH.  It shows a steady warming trend  of roughly 0.12 C per decade or 1.2 C per century with peaks at the el nino years (1998, 2016)
http://www.nsstc.uah.edu/climate/2016/july/July2016_graph.png
What is your reason to believe that this rate is greater than the rate of warming for the 100 years preceding it?

text: format - what is driving the current global temperature trend has been fully investigated. The rise in CO2 is due to human activity not any else. A rise in CO2 is predicted to cause the global temperature to rise in the pattern observed. All other possible causes in the last 100 years have been examined, and all natural causes have been eliminated as playing a significant role. The rise in temperature is not steady, in part because of the way the oceans absorb the heat, in part due to volcanic activity, in part due to particular and sulphur dioxide emissions and likely in part due to the limitations in estimating global temperature in any year. It has been determined that the global rise in temperature over the last 100 years is almost entirely attributable to human activity. The fall in temperature following WWII is mostly attributed to the large amount of sulphur emitted into the atmosphere from burning coal. This was removed from the emissions by the 80s.

author: format .c

text:
format - you need to be more careful in the way that you use your language. What does "The greenhouse effect was correct " mean? Are you suggesting that the greenhouse effect has been proven? If so, how?
You then claim that Michael Faraday was correct. Are you suggesting that everything that Michael Faraday said was correct. I am not playing word games here. There is a general acceptance of many physical principles, but all of them can be found to based on an incorrect belief, and that current theory may fail in conditions that have not yet been tested. And even in the conditions that have been tested, it is an assumption that an experiment will always behave as predicted. There is absolutely no way of proving that something will definitely happen, however we have great confidence in things because they seem to follow a pattern.
You are using the word 'fact' carelessly also. In science a fact is an observation, or data that we use to support or disprove an hypothesis. In general terms a fact is something that is accepted as true. Whether something is described as a fact or not is dependent on the audience and the context. Some may well claim that it is a fact that CO2 is the reason why the earth's temperature has gone up, they are that certain. The problem is that the people that are very certain are not the sort of people who would use the word fact in that manner, and the people who might use the word in that manner don't know enough to be confident of calling it a fact. This is one the many problems science has in communicating with the general public. What they say is interpreted differently depending on who is hearing it.

"More interesting is that scientists now understand clearly that this huge flame ball called the sun is 99% responsible for the earths temperature." - what does that mean? How do you get that measurement of 99%? If you consider a case when the sun is there to when it is not the answer would be 100%. If you consider the case of when the greenhouse effect is there and not the answer is 90%. And I haven't even moved on to considering seasons. In any case it is not the magnitude of the contribution (if that could be measured), but the magnitude of the contribution to any change over a particular time scale. Let me put it this way - you could argue that in a perfectly insulated building where the temperature is controlled by a AC unit that the electricity is 100% responsible for the temperature. But it is the people who set actually control the temperature so maybe they are 100% responsible.

"The planets temperature will start decreasing because suns activity has started to decrease" - what time scale are you talking on? There is a 11 year cycle, but that doesn't affect the long term trend. The long term trend of the sun is to get warmer, and this will result in the extinction of all complex life forms in 500 million year's time.

"Earths climate is something we would never be able to control." - what do you base that claim on? Why would that be impossible? Apparently you know something that climatologists don't.

"Recycling, turning off devices when we don tuse them, taking the bus instead of your car etc that is all great stuff" - what has this got to do with whether or not the heating over the last 100years is anthropogenic? 

"Interfering with nature is something terrible humans do and they should stop immediately." - that is impossible. You can consider that we are either part of nature or not. If we are part of nature then it's not interference. If we are not then everything we do is interference. You seem to have drawn an arbitrary line where some human actions are natural and some are not.

"You wanna know more about saving the planet shit?" - no, I want you to stop spreading misinformation.

author: Logann Hogue

text:
+TheWeasle

"#1 That 97% of scientists agreeing is completely misconstrued. That 97% references only around 70 scientists agreeing."

Nope. Stop pretending that Anderegg et al. was the only study on this. There were multiple studies showing the consensus. For example:

Table 1: "Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming"
"Does it matter if the consensus on anthropogenic global warming is 97% or 99.99%?"
Page 49 of: "Models, manifestation and attribution of climate change"



"#2 Ice sheets have increased by 120 billion tons a year from 1998-2001 and increased by 80 billion tons from 2003-2008."

Both the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets have net ice loss.

The Greenland melt is covered in sources such as:

"A high-resolution record of Greenland mass balance"
"Antarctica, Greenland and Gulf of Alaska land-ice evolution from an iterated GRACE global mascon solution"
"Greenland and Antarctica ice sheet mass changes and effects on global sea level"

Your claim on increasing Antarctic ice is likely based on a NASA press release about an Antarctic ice study:

https://climate.nasa.gov/news/2361/study-mass-gains-of-antarctic-ice-sheet-greater-than-losses/
"Mass gains of the Antarctic ice sheet exceed losses"

The study in question is an outlier; the study's results contradict numerous other papers that show decreasing Antarctic ice levels. There have also been questions raised about the study's results and methods. And NASA acknowledges that Antarctic ice is decreasing:

https://climate.nasa.gov/vital-signs/land-ice/

Some background on this (especially figure 1 of the first paper):

"Comment on ‚ÄòMass gains of the Antarctic ice sheet exceed losses‚Äô by H. J. Zwally and others"
"Comment on Zwally and others (2015)-Mass gains of the Antarctic ice sheet exceed losses"
"Spatial and temporal Antarctic Ice Sheet mass trends, glacio-isostatic adjustment, and surface processes from a joint inversion of satellite altimeter, gravity, and GPS data"
"A data-driven approach for assessing ice-sheet mass balance in space and time"
"Greenland and Antarctica ice sheet mass changes and effects on global sea level"
"A comparison of Antarctic ice sheet surface mass balance from atmospheric climate models and in situ observations"



"#3 These predictions have been proven false many times. Scientists predicted that humans will die due to climate change in 2013"

Stop making up stuff for which you've cited no evidence.



"#4 What happened to the theory in the 1970s of Global Cooling that was going to happen? Today's scientists contradicted that claim."

Stop falling for Internet myths. More of the scientific community was predicting imminent global warming in the 1970s, than were predicting imminent global cooling. Go do some reading on this:

"The myth of the 1970s global cooling scientific consensus"
"The idea of anthropogenic global climate change in the 20th century"

"Rebuttals to Climate Myths
[...]
However, the most comprehensive study in the 1970s was the 1975 report by the US National Academy of Sciences and National Research Council that concluded, "‚Ä¶ we do not have a good quantitative understanding of our climate machine and what determines its course." This qualified statement is in strong contrast with the current position of the US National Academy of Science: ‚ÄúThe scientific understanding of climate change is now sufficiently clear to justify nations taking prompt action." To compare the handful of cooling predictions in the 1970s (predominantly from media sources, not peer-reviewed literature) to the current scientific consensus endorsing human-caused global warming, is both inappropriate and misleading."



"#5 If scientists can't predict what the weather and temperature will be in 3 days from now, how can they predict what it will be like decades or centuries from now? It is illogical to predict nature."

As silly as saying:

"If you can't predict whether the heads-to-tails ratio will be 2:2 or 3:1 or 0:4 for 4 coin flips, then how can you predict that the ratio will be close to 2:2 for 4 million coin flips?"

Do you understand that long-term trends are often easier to predict that shorter-term fluctuations? Apparently you don't, so you're (to use your term) illogical.

potholer54 will dumb this down for you more in his videos below:

"Why global temperatures never go up in straight lines" (especially from 5:22 - 11:22)
"8. Climate Change -- Has the Earth been cooling?"
"8a. Climate Change - Phil Jones and the 'no warming for 15 years'"

text:
I know water expands when you freeze it.

Common sense tells me that when you heat up water to 200 degrees other variables, for example the water evaporating (yes, water can evaporate without boiling) come into play. For example, water is 'sticky' and thus can go over the top without spilling. text: I'll offer the science of this, as in my schooling over nine chemistry courses, and three physics to include physics chemistry was taken.  Gaseous molecules, of any sort, reflect or refract light.  And light being any wavelength in or outside the visible spectrum (ROYGBIV).  Each atom does this, and is why you see certain colors on fabric, in the rainbow, and in your daily life.  CO2, of any isotope (difference atomic mass) refracts UV, and other light waves (and particles).  The light that does make it to the surface and bounces off after passing some energy (infrared heat), cannot or finds it difficult to escape the upper atmosphere.  It continues to be sent back and forth until eventually it escapes.  Heat is transferred from the light, as its component of kinetic energy.  So, the Earth's surface will heat up, however little it does.  Now, that I've laid that out, let's use it to discuss your water experiment.  If you have H2O in your pot, and regardless of temp, unless frozen, some of those molecules will escape the "liquid" phase, as other atoms in the air have transferred kinetic energy to the H2O, just by colliding with another molecule, which can be enough to break the hydrogen-bonds with other molecules.  As the liquid is supplied with heat, the molecules vibrate more and more, and thus the volume of the liquid will expand, at the molecular level.  How does it apply to the large scale?  Well, if you were to put a lid on it, if you're cooking rice or potatoes for example, you've reduced the ability for gaseous molecules to escape.  So, it will expand even more (pressure), and eventually boil over.
author: Jason Crum

text: + Michael Weston When ice is heated from 0 to 4 degrees C, it does contract. The water molecules get closer together and the water occupies less volume. However, above 4 degrees C water expands as it is heated, like most other liquids. This temperature is in the realm of much of the worlds oceans. In general, heat makes solids, liquids, and gasses expand.

text: 'Khyron Kravshera',  Estimates within climatology vary regarding exactly when man-made CO2 became the dominant factor in global warming.  Most estimates that I've seen place it somewhere between 1950 and 1975, but in order to know exactly how much warming is natural vs man-made, you would need to know the exact climate sensitivity.  Uncertainties remain which prohibit an exact conclusion, such as global cloud cover and how it has responded.  However, from what I've seen, this only restrains us from knowing whether our CO2 emissions will exacerbate natural warming is a problematic way or a catastrophic way (so to speak).

The heat-trapping nature of carbon dioxide and other gases was demonstrated in the mid-19th century. Water vapor concentrations in the air are controlled by Earth‚Äôs temperature. So only small changes of carbon dioxide can cause big changes in the Earth's temperature. 
Models have been created which accurately predict past climate changes. These same models predict a warming of the earth's climate. The same models without human input do not predict global warming. (or at least considerably less so)

text: man bear pig The earth has been heating and cooling over billions of years because of the solar cycle. This solar cycle is caused by the sun spots that appear when there is more solar activity. When there is more solar activity, there are less clouds and when there is less solar activity then there are more clouds. Clouds are linked to cosmic rays, so when there are more cosmic rays the temperature is colder. The amount of cosmic rays hitting the earth is linked to the solar activity. Everything we know about climate change is linked back to the sun. Climate change is real, but it's not caused by CO2. You have to realize how little CO2 is in the air compared to other greenhouse gases. The most important greenhouse gas is water vapor. People also talk about the melting of the Antarctic and I want you to know that when you see a video of the ice breaking off, this is about as naturally occurring as leaves from from a tree. Ice is always moving, the ice in in Antarctic is also going through a cycle where it expands and contracts. There is a connection between CO2 and temperature, but it's not that CO2 is what drives temperature. It's the fact that temperature drives CO2. The Ocean has a memory of the temperature of our past. The ocean is so big that for it to heat and cool it takes hundreds of years for the actual temperature of the ocean to change from whatever event happened. It's almost the same as when you look at a star and what you're seeing is what occurred long ago. There is a lag between temperature and CO2 because of how long it takes the ocean to heat and cool. The warmer it is, the more CO2 will be released and the colder it is more CO2 will be sucked in by the ocean. Humans are not emitting CO2 at a rate where it's causing climate change, volcanoes give off more CO2 than people, cars, and factories do combined. There is no direct connection between higher CO2 levels leading to higher temperature. In the last 120 years, most of the temperature change happened even before the post war economic boom. If CO2 were to have a connection to temperature, then the years after the war should have been a time where the temperature was rising but instead the opposite happened. If you have any questions feel free to ask.
author: Mathew Raimbault

text: If the earth has been heating and cooling forever how can you attribute any recent change to human activity?
author: man bear pig

text: That's a very important question. Recently solar activity has started to decrease and in the past this always meant that the earth should be cooling as well but instead we've seen an increase in temperatures. Scientists need more time to gather data to explain the recent changes to climate, this is why it is such a popular topic. There are many different theories to why this is happening. When the surface temperature of the earth increases, the temperature of the upper layer of the atmosphere should be increasing rapidly but scientists have seen that it hasn't been drastic at all. If this were to be true, then the theory that greenhouse gases are even effecting climate change at all would be false. In my opinion, there must be a factor that has shown up recently that has never shown up before that is causing this rise in temperature. As I said before, temperature is what drives CO2. So in my opinion, if in the past when there were CO2 levels even higher than now, that still means that even in current time it is not effecting climate. One of the most important things to do while discussing climate change is to keep an open mind and see what is to come. Humans might have some sort of effect on climate change but because it's natural, I don't think it will cause anything that we will have to worry about. I'm a Geology major and have had many conversations about this topic with my professors. To make a long story short if someone asks you what you think about climate change, it's safe to say solar activity has definitely had an effect on climate change in the past but recently that might no longer be the case. Not saying it has no effect on temperature at all anymore, just saying there must be another factor contributing to what is happening that is not from CO2 emissions.
author: Mathew Raimbault

text: 222ableVelo a correlation between data can only be incorrect if the math is wrong. This math has been checked by literally thousands of people with advanced training in mathematics and they believe that the math checks out. It is true that correlation does not imply causation. However, careful measurements have demonstrated that human activity is by far the largest source of carbon dioxide and methane on the planet: the measured spike in atmospheric carbon since the industrial revolution cannot be accounted for by volcanic or biological sources. We have demonstrated that the physical properties of these gasses cause them to trap heat more effectively than other gasses in our atomatsphere, and that the measured increase in temperature of the earth and ocean corresponds with what would be expected given the measured changes in atmospheric carbon and the aforementioned physical properties. 222ableVelo, please let me know what is wrong with these arguments, and why you don't feel they are convincing.

author: quizr

text:
I don't deny that humans affect their environment.¬†¬†Of course they affect their environment.¬† That's not the question, the question here is whether or not humans are the reason for "global average"¬†temperature increases.¬† And I don't believe they are.¬† For one thing, the Earth is huge......some people don't realize just how huge the Earth actually is.¬† And it's resilient.¬† It has many mechanisms for correcting itself, atmospherically speaking.¬† What humans are currently doing in terms of pollution is extremely insignificant to even remotely affect global atmospheric conditions.¬† It's like¬†a drop in the bucket.¬† Man-caused global warming is NOT happening.

Plants love CO2.¬† So IF CO2 was out of control, the plants/trees on our planet would be using this extra CO2 even more, and be very effective counter-weights to the CO2 being put into the air.¬† Secondly, CO2 only makes up .04% of the entire atmosphere.¬† Water vapor, on the other hand, has more to do with the "greenhouse effect" people are so worried about a LOT more than CO2 does.¬† And, more importantly,¬†water vapor makes up a lot more of the atmosphere than does CO2.¬† So, why are people worried about¬†relatively small¬†rises in CO2 levels, when water vapor has significantly more to do with it?

So, yes, quizr,¬†you can call me a Neanderthal if you want, but¬†I'll call you a fool for believing in bad science, bad methodologies, and for not correctly assessing all causal factors.¬† Not just you, but these "scientists" spouting this nonsense.

You guys can have fun¬†denying yourself¬†easy energy in order to fix something that isn't broken.¬† But you're going to cost us trillions (if not more) of dollars in trying to do so, and it will all be in vain.¬† And that is extremely reprehensible.
author: 222ableVelo

text:
'222ableVelo',  I'd be willing to discuss this, if you'd like.  I'm not looking for a throat to rip or anything--this topic is just a hobby of mine.  I'll address some of these things below, in summary:

Regarding the size of the Earth, it's important to note that we've had global impacts before, such as chlorofluorocarbon emissions and the ozone layer, which is still recovering (to my knowledge) thanks to laws restricting CFC release.  Consider the collection of plastic in the oceans which remains for long periods of time, similar to long-lived greenhouse gasses, like CO2.  That CO2 gets scrubbed from the atmosphere, into the oceans, at a rate which doesn't keep-up with the continuous release.  As a result, it accumulates in the atmosphere.

The effects of small percentages of CO2 can be amplified by that water vapor you mentioned, and more importantly, cloud cover.  Concerning plant growth and CO2, you must consider the changes in rainfall as well, which are quicker to affect plants.  After all, water is more important than slight CO2 increases to plant growth.  It's likely that as the world warms, the El Nino/La Nina phenomenon will produce an increasing contrast in rainfall.

text:
What's been very different since the last century is the increase of human population. In a hundred years, we went from a population of 1.6 billion people in 1900 to 7.0 billion in 2016, and that change alone in terms of human activity is why that second graph you sent has a large temperature spike in the last 50 years rather than a curve like the centuries before. As for the blog, it's important to note that the man who planned out that study is meteorologist and not a climatologist, which can make differences in how a case study is approached.

Solar irradiance can affect climate change, true, but more at a smaller scale. According to Goddard Space Flight Center: http://www.nasa.gov/centers/goddard/news/topstory/2008/solar_variability.html, solar heat is only related to about 25% of the overall temperature changes, with humans being the number one factor since 1950, which you can see in the first graph on this site: https://www3.epa.gov/climatechange/science/causes.html

author: Pancho Lopez

text:
With atmospheric CO2 concentrations reaching the 400 ppm level, the  media and a number of alarmist scientists have set off the mega-alarm bells, claiming ‚Äúrecord high levels‚Äù of CO2 had been reached, and that the planet is on the verge of an overdose. This is based purely on ignorance of the Earth‚Äôs history.

Worrying that 400 ppm is too high is like worrying about your fuel tank overflowing when it reaches the 1/8 mark during filling.

From a historical perspective, an atmospheric CO2 concentration of 400 ppm is actually almost scraping the bottom of the barrel. Over the Earth‚Äôs history, atmospheric CO2 concentrations have ranged from 180 ppm
 to 7000 ppm.  On that scale we are in fact today barely above the Earth‚Äôs record lows.

That 400 ppm is actually dangerously low is a fact the alarmists keep avoiding and suppressing. Below 150 ppm, plant-life dies off on a massive scale. The Earth actually came very close to that point many times over the last 2 million years during the ice ages. At the bottom of the last ice age just 20,000 years ago, life on the planet literally 
teetered on the brink¬†when CO2 fell to a¬†level of just 180 ppm. Do we really want to live on the brink of extinction?  It‚Äôs a fact that biologists have shown that once the atmospheric CO2 level falls below the 500 ppm level, plants really begin to suffer.

No one disputes that man‚Äôs activities have helped to increase atmospheric CO2 concentration, and it should not be in dispute that plants and life on the planet are thankful that man has done so. At 400 ppm, the planet is a safer place to be and will be even safer at 1000 ppm.

author: Alpha Capricorni

text:
¬†@Alpha Capricorni¬† really? Find a single paper that goes against AGW. Plants adapting to a higher temperature means the plant is adapting to a higher temperature. This does not conclude human impact is the cause. 

97% is a nonsensical number that was put forward by a graduate student in their thesis. This has been debunked and proven inaccurate quite a while ago. Scott, it is vital to keep a neutral stance in science and navigate your consensuses based on the end roots of the scientific method. 

We cannot predict climate patterns to any degree of accuracy, our models are 65p at theoretical variability (lets not even talk practical) - where is the certainty that you speak of? Our planet is a rock full of microbes and geochemical concentration gradients in atmospheric layers. We are orbiting a star with a dwindling magnetic pole with an ever changing spin orientation, within solar cycling and an uncertainty in our oceans behaviour. The gravitational stress is highly variable on our atmosphere and our wobble is extremely difficult to predict.  Excuse me for doubting the absolute certainty of our planets character. I have read over 1,000 scientific papers in this field. A marine biologist who works in the field of coral reefs is going to naturally link carbonic acidity to bleaching, which they then are going to more than likely link to anthropogenic climate change. This is an opinion using carbon concentration as the foundation for an argument. This does not mean that it is true, leaked deep ocean carbonic acid that we have not explored could be responsible for differing oceanic geochemistry. The variability of IR Radiation on the plant could perpetuate a higher or lower yield of energy regulation and chemical degradation. A marine biologist is not trained in atmospheric physics or geochemistry and therefore who's analysis of the earth should be put into context. 

There is a high certainty that a species of 7+ billion whom is mining and chemically altering gaseous byproducts is most likely going to impact the earth in some way. We could very well be the leading cause behind our variability and the reason our evidence is not substantial is due to lagging chemical concentration gradients or a completely different reason that we are not aware of. However, we haven't PROVED anything. If you read an article that says "hottest on record" - that is a bias. On what record? Who recorded this? How did they record this? What exactly are they recording? How long have they been recording? I don't care about what scientists think, I think for myself, I am my own academic and I formulate my own scientific consensus through my lens of knowledge awareness.

text: It's not a serious issue, it's just natural fluctuations. Stop spreading lies Bill Nye the Shill guy! His stats are all complete garbage. The 97% consensus is a concocted lie. Cook and others have published papers claiming that 97% of scientists agree that man made global warming is a big problem but this has been refuted by proper analysis and direct polls.

Secondly, the people who are saying we have a big problem have tried to explain how big the problem is by using fraud like the Hockey Stick graph. And then asking for money.

Third, the people who are saying we have a big problem have been saying we have a big problem for decades, and all of their predictions about what the problem would cause haven't come to pass. And then they asked for money. 

And lastly, and this is the big one for anyone with an ounce of sense:

THE PEOPLE WHO ARE TELLING US THERE IS A BIG PROBLEM DO NOT LIVE THEIR LIVES AS IF THE BIG PROBLEM REALLY EXISTS!

You and I could put up charts and graphs for years going back and forth. But really, if you honestly want to know how big the problem is, we only need one graph. 

The graph of Leonardo DiCaprio's carbon footprint compared to the average person's carbon footprint.

author: youngbloodx

text:
+10thyoung 
I'm disinterested in Snowden's opinions on the subject. 
Let's take seriously, for a moment, the real phenomenon that a particular industry or academic research area (or religion, or any other social group) that feels under siege tends to become more orthodox and less tolerant of opinions that vary from the Scripture/official press release/company line. How do we know when an orthodoxy is wrong, or when it's right?
1) Who does a better job of accounting for the other side's facts? In this case, the answer is clear. People against global warming usually bring factoids to the table, whereas people who see it as a real problem can put those factoids into context to demonstrate that it is in fact still a problem. "What a cold winter; I guess global warming is bunk!" "No. In fact some regions may become colder even though the overall temperature rises, and we predict more extreme weather events other than droughts."
2) What do other related groups say about it? The strong consensus even among other academic fields is that global warming is real. 
3) Is either side speaking out of their mouths? "Sure, global warming doesn't exist, but even if it does look at this study on crop yields."

author: Lee Duon

text:
+Lee Duon 

So you have read the studies which say the exact opposite of what you are claiming?  The studies which show that the reefs which are declining are the ones visited by humans, and also those which have shown reefs with high levels of local pH reduction (to be clear, the water is still basic, just slightly less so) are doing just fine?  The basic problem here is that the political community has religion:  CO2 is the cause of all (bad) things environmental.  If something bad happens in the environment, such people ask "how did CO2 cause this".  Not "how did this happen".  If your assumption is that CO2 has to be the cause then of course you will find arguments for how fragile the coral is against pH.  But we know that corals have survived much lower pH from the geological record.  The modern CO2 is 8X less than times which corals thrived in.  So not only do we have recent studies, but historical evidence as well.
author: Keeman

text: Water vapor is a natural process that keeps this planet from freezing. It's just that small percentage that tips the balance of the scale. Natural climate change has occurred hundreds of times in our past. While Earth has an almost circular orbit, it has a super-schedule that causes the Earth to come closer to our sun, and if that coincides with a particular tilt of the planet, then you can experience global warming/global cooling. Today, however, we are warming up far faster than we should, and we can likely contribute this to industrial human era greenhouse emissions.

The Earth's climate has changed throughout history. Just in the last 650,000 years there have been seven cycles of glacial advance and retreat, with the abrupt end of the last ice age about 7,000 years ago marking the beginning of the modern climate era ‚Äî and of human civilization. Most of these climate changes are attributed to very small variations in Earth‚Äôs orbit that change the amount of solar energy our planet receives.The current warming trend is of particular significance because most of it is very likely human-induced and proceeding at a rate that is unprecedented in the past 1,300 years.1
Earth-orbiting satellites and other technological advances have enabled scientists to see the big picture, collecting many different types of information about our planet and its climate on a global scale. This body of data, collected over many years, reveals the signals of a changing climate.The heat-trapping nature of carbon dioxide and other gases was demonstrated in the mid-19th century.2¬†Their ability to affect the transfer of infrared energy through the atmosphere is the scientific basis of many instruments flown by NASA. There is no question that increased levels of greenhouse gases must cause the Earth to warm in response. SOURCE NASA
Scientific evidence for warming of the climate system is unequivocal.
- Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
The Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets have decreased in mass. Data from NASA's Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment show Greenland lost 150 to 250 cubic kilometers (36 to 60 cubic miles) of ice per year between 2002 and 2006, while Antarctica lost about 152 cubic kilometers (36 cubic miles) of ice between 2002 and 2005. Source NASA
A new study by researchers at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration finds that the world‚Äôs warming never really stalled during the last 15 years‚Äîit was just masked by incomplete data records that have been improved and expanded in recent years."The rate of temperature increase during the last half of the 20th century is virtually identical to that of the 21st century," said Tom Karl, director of¬†NOAA's¬†National Centers for Environmental Information and lead author of the study.

author: Ragnaar Minnesota

text:
¬†@Ragnaar Minnesota¬†
"CO2 causes a small amount of warming. Water vapor multiplies that. That is accepted science. How much does it multiply it?"

Water vapor is seen as an amplifying force because you can't have more long term water vapor in a given climate without increasing the temperatures first because of this magical process known as condensation. If it's not in the atmosphere it can't act as a green house gas.

" The point of the science is policy? Do we agree on that? "

No, the point of the science is to inform what's most likely to be true, policy is independent because politicians not scientists make the laws and set policy, they do so all the time in contradiction to the best science.

"The answer we still have is X to 3X."

It's a statistical statement, and it's actually closer to x and 2.25x. If the only factor at play were CO2 it'd be a pretty easy calculation since it's a simple blackbody calculation. the range is to signify the various other factors at play which can include unknown knowns.

" Nothing of what you wrote deals with whether we are the cause of most of this?"

You never asked and don't seem all that interested.

It's actually pretty easy, different forms of warming have different fingerprints, We can attribute warming to different sources based on specific fingerprints. There are several fingerprints unique to CO2 based warming and it's the strongest fingerprint in the instrumental record.

For example CO2 will warm the lower troposphere but actually cool the upper atmosphere (this has been observed), We can detect the increase in downwards long wave radiation along the specific wavelengths of the ghgs involved (as different ghgs absorb different wavelengths of light, which is also observed), we can calculate the increase of energy that would give us.

Even if we had zero long term data on the topic the fact that you can test the physical mechanism and perform such an attribution study is what indicates it's most likely to be the primary cause of recent warming. If you presented nothing more than this to me with regards to recent data, I would be hard pressed to find fault with it because it's so specific in nature.

Arguing "we don't have enough long term data" is like if I heated a pot of water with ignited propane gas, I measured the light spectrum it emitted, the heat it emitted, measured the gas being burned, and how the pot of water heated from the bottom up and then arguing that I didn't know what the pot was doing 50 years ago so I can't attribute current warming to the flame.

If you want a similar analogy to the pot, maybe I try and heat it using different methods, you can still determine what's the most likely cause of most of the warming by testing the different specific mechanisms and find the most likely cause of most of the warming. While it'll be more difficult to find what warmed the pot 50 years ago, it doesn't invalidate all of the specific measurements and mechanisms because I don't have data from that pot from 50 years ago, particularly when I'm talking about what's causing the warming now.

All the same, if you actually plan on making decisions and the majority of temperature change in that range is deemed pretty bad by most accounts for both the world economy and the environment you'd think that you'd want to take action based on being informed so.

If you want to focus on "well they're not 100% certain" nothing in science is, particularly things like this were virtually everything is statistical in nature, but if you have a better method that takes into account all of the relevant evidence I'm waiting to hear it.

3) The larger pot of water includes the oceans and I don't think in net they are a a wash. OHC has had Argo for less than two decades."

author: garith21

text:
Yes, Santer has worked on this. Looks like he used a GCM comparing natural to CO2 forced runs. With CO2 the upper atmosphere cools and it doesn't with the natural runs. So he concludes it's the CO2 doing it and calls it a fingerprint. A typical GCM might have grid cells with a size of about 100 km. 10,000 square kilometers per grid cell. He is respected, it was published. I'd be happier with a grid cell size of 1 km and that's still going to miss a lot. 

When looking at the longwave spectrum yes, that has changed. CO2 is doing what they said it would. What about everything thing else? I keep looking at Humlum's water vapor data. It's flat. And has been as CO2 keeps rising. Call it a fingerprint of CO2 alone and not the expected water vapor. Why haven't they done a similar study showing the expected increased water vapor? All the info was teed up for them to say, And there's that additional water vapor keeping longwave radiation around, we told you was going to be there too.
You are quoting the IPCC on the 95% certainty. That was their judgment. This guy says it more like 43% of scientists:https://fabiusmaximus.com/2015/07/29/new-study-undercuts-ipcc-keynote-finding-87796/
author: Ragnaar Minnesota

text:
¬†@Ragnaar Minnesota¬†
" Yes, Santer has worked on this. Looks like he used a GCM comparing natural to CO2 forced runs."

It's pretty much a natural result of the physics of more long wave radiation staying in the troposphere, ergo not getting into the upper stratosphere resulting in less energy reaching it in a set amount of time for a given amount of sunlight.

"I keep looking at Humlum's water vapor data."

Yeah, going to need you to cite your sources on this one.

http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/full/10.1175/JCLI3990.1

"we told you was going to be there too."

Who's this "we", how many of you are there in there?

"You are quoting the IPCC on the 95% certainty. "

There are differences between levels of statistical confidence based on attribution studies and number of practicing scientists that are convinced to that degree and producing relevant scientific literature.

My claim was on the statistical attribution studies for which the polled scientists may or may not be aware of. Even then most are convinced that it's still the primary cause of most of the warming even if not to the 95th percentile.

Not to mention the source of your post is well, dubious, but I'll even grant it.

A main issue is that the side claiming to be skeptics still don't care to explain the phenomenon with their own hypothesis and ones that are often the most popular are actually very easy to disprove with the observations. Much like in the day of cigarette campaigns trying to focus on the uncertainties in lung cancer causes it only focuses on known weaknesses while ignoring the data on hand that give reasonable certainty.

Like "it's the sun" can be disproved by several different angles including we have direct observations of the sun, there's no mechanism by which the sun would simultaneously warm the troposphere but cool the upper stratosphere, that the sun would warm the poles quicker than the equator, that events like the laschamp anomaly bring into great question the idea that cosmic rays could be a primary factor in effecting long term climate.

The reason why popular skeptics don't really make positive declarations any more is because they've been dismissed by the physics and observations, it's easier to try and knock anything down than it is to actually support something.

I don't claim to be an expert, but the vast majority of evidence is convincing to me with regards to the topic and skeptic arguments are drastically lacking in this regard. Again when it comes to planning for the future you still go with what is most likely true based on your best available information.

Everyone already agrees that we would like better data, but nothing changes the fact that we still only have what we have, skeptics need to produce something better if they really want things to go in another direction with regards to this topic rather than whining that it'll never be good enough because (for some reason) we need things like a thousand years more data because no one in the skeptic community can really seem to determine what's "enough data" to be convinced of a trend or a mechanism. Judging by the complaints, half the time I think they want a million years of instrumental data, but no one will seem to say what's good enough for them.

text:
If you're on the fence about whether to believe that climate change is real or not, please check out the link below, which clears up a lot of the common myths that have been spreading around:
https://www.skepticalscience.com/argument.php

It's really frustrating that so much resistance has been made against the climate change science. Even if you are skeptical and say that maybe there's a 50/50 chance that the climate change scientists are right, shouldn't we do something about it? If NASA said that there's a 50% chance that an asteroid will hit our planet, causing lots of lives to be lost, lots of people to lose their homes, huge changes to the planet's ecology, etc, would people really be this apathetic? The effects of climate change that science has predicted are incredibly dangerous, and we are already seeing many of them today - extreme weather, heat waves, rise in sea levels, destruction of coral reefs... the list goes on and on.

We humans can survive temperature drastic temperature changes, our crops can't, the microbes in the oceans can't, the Global Oceanic Conveyor Belt can't. All of these thing sustain human life and thus our culture.
Will humans survives in a hotter world? Sure. But with our crops dying and our oceans putrid we aren't really going to be able to eat much and that's a problem if you want to continue living. 
Before the industrial revolution, the human population was around a Billion world wide and that was pretty consistent for most of humanity including in the pre-agriculture era. 
We were able to sustain this population by living off the land and cultivating crops. The world provided and we took what we needed to survive.

Climate Change means global starvation which means a lot of desperate people. A lot of desperate people leads to war and a lot of it. We will be too busy fighting for scraps to fix our planet.
author: Ryan H-W

text:
+Racks on Racks You sound like a scientific illiterate. Firstly, you don't seem to understand how evolution works. Evolution is driven by random mutation + natural selection. Random mutation over the course of only 2 generation per 1 century is incredibly small. But let's assume that some people already are genetically simply more capable of surviving at hotter temperature. However, such people do not possess an actual larger chance of surviving.  We have homes, hats, and sunblock all which protect us from heat. Natural selection isn't going to affect humans a lot. It will affect us in directly through food/water sources.

But the more important concerning factor is the life of other animals which would be threatened, thus affecting our food supply. Fresh water sources will be devastated as well since rivers and lakes wlll shrink. 

The only way we'll "evolve" to be better at living in warmer temperature is, black melanin rich skin, more sweat glands,  taller and skinnier bodies (better heat dissipation). For us to evolve into that, lot of people that is light skinned, shorter and of stockier build will have to die out. That's not going to happen, any time or ever. Human advances prevent that, just like how we use clothes to survive in colder temperatures.

text:
+Aanthanur DC +Jack Hooper There is no evidence unequivocally linking the very minimal warming occurring currently to anthropogenic activity. Neither in the short nor long term. There are specious assertions, fraudulent data, and there are claims of bizarre 97% consensuses. There is wildly inaccurate CMIP-5 predictions. CAGW theory is predicated on the assumption that the climate is highly sensitive to carbon dioxide. Guesswork. The new science.

As for the phony "consensus" claim...
http://judithcurry.com/2015/12/20/what-is-there-a-97-consensus-about/

Here's a small list of scientists who denounce anthropomorphic 
climate-change:
David Bellamy, botanist. Lennart Bengtsson, meteorologist, Reading 
University.
Piers Corbyn, owner of the business WeatherAction which makes weather 
forecasts, astrophysicist. 
Judith Curry, Professor and former chair of the School of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences at the Georgia Institute of Technology.
Freeman Dyson, professor emeritus of the School of Natural Sciences, 
Institute for Advanced Study; Fellow of the Royal Society.
Steven E. Koonin, theoretical physicist and director of the Center for 
Urban Science and Progress at New York University
Richard Lindzen, Alfred P. Sloan emeritus professor of atmospheric 
science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and member of the 
National Academy of Sciences.
Craig Loehle, ecologist and chief scientist at the National Council for 
Air and Stream Improvement.
Patrick Moore, former president of Greenpeace Canada.
Nils-Axel M√∂rner, retired head of the Paleogeophysics and Geodynamics 
Department at Stockholm University, former chairman of the INQUA 
Commission on Sea Level Changes and Coastal Evolution (1999‚Äì2003).
Garth Paltridge, retired chief research scientist, CSIRO Division of 
Atmospheric Research and retired director of the Institute of the 
Antarctic Cooperative Research Centre, visiting fellow Australian 
National University.
Tom Quirk, corporate director of biotech companies and former board 
member of the Institute of Public Affairs, an Australian conservative 
think-tank.
Denis Rancourt, former professor of physics at University of Ottawa, 
research scientist in condensed matter physics, and in environmental and
 soil science.
Harrison Schmitt, geologist, Apollo 17 Astronaut, former U.S. Senator.
Peter Stilbs, professor of physical chemistry at Royal Institute of 
Technology, Stockholm. Philip Stott, professor emeritus of biogeography 
at the University of London.
Hendrik Tennekes, retired director of research, Royal Netherlands 
Meteorological Institute.
Anastasios Tsonis, distinguished professor at the University of 
Wisconsin-Milwaukee. Fritz Vahrenholt, German politician and energy

Basically he said that if global warming does not turn out to be a serious problem this century it will in centuries to come because of the "long tail" of co2 in the atmosphere (something David Archer explains well) and the increase in the  greenhouse effect of co2. This is assuming we just keep on burning everything we can get our hands on. On the subject of methane, David Archer expressed less concern about a huge slug of methane added to the atmosphere as compared to a persistent increase in co2 because methane gets cycled out in about 12 years whereas co2 takes centuries. Provide one piece of evidence impartially agreed upon by climate change denying and proponent scientists alike, which offers significant data against global warming, to supplant your geopolitical arguments. 
Granted, I am also skeptical that 97% of scientists agree upon this issue. But from almost all sources, it is a majority.But please provide impartial scientific evidence, beyond bare statistics of a single year, event, that has come from a reliable source, which successfully refutes the greenhouse effect.

author: John Dezelski

text:
+LA Kid, "reputable source" has become just another fallacy!

This site was created to defend the consensus claim but you can use it to debunk the consensus. Make a login, rate some abstracts, and compare your results. Even if you rate abstracts the same you can see how they misrepresent the data. Look for bandwagon support in abstracts but the work done has no basis for it. Also look for them to count things that are not relevant to the central question. For example, a study of carbon sequestration attempts to answer the question, "Can we sequester carbon" but is treated as though it asks "Do we need to sequester carbon." Those are very different questions. 

The sources you don't feel like using can help you find other problems with it as well. 

http://www.skepticalscience.com/tcp.php?t=home
author: John Dezelski

Let me repeat, the Consensus Project was created by John Cook, the lead author of the Quantifying the Consensus paper and it disproves his own claims!

If you want to argue with me you better not rely on such feeble excuses as "I don't feel like doing the work to figure it out."

We need to stop hyperfocusing on a specific % because it leads to nothing anyway.

text:
The consensus isn't a lie. The 97% figure specifically refers to the aggregation of papers published in peer review taking on the issue of climate change. Of the papers that talk about it, 97% take a positive stance it exists.¬†

In the field of climate science itself, acceptance of AGW is also high, but not 97%. It's like 88-90% depending on the organization you poll (National Academy, for example).¬†

Acceptance of AGW declines only if you dishonestly poll random people who have no credentials in climate science or you include mathematicians, biologists, economists etc. That is often what the denier lists do. They use the term "scientist" to refer to things like economists, as if their opinion matters.¬†

text:
Yep, I knew Bill was gunna use that '97% of scientists agree' lie. Man, there's just something about that long debunked factoid that's just irresistible to these propagandists. Wanna know how someone is brainlessly spouting propaganda bullcrap about MMGW? Listen for the "97% of Scientists agree" line. This little factoid has been endlessly repeated by the propagandists, and it has actually already been thoroughly debunked.

For those who haven't heard, that statistic was based on the most manipulative, (and outright dishonest) practices of John Cook, an Australian "Scientist" back in 2009 who counted pretty much ANY paper that mentioned Global Warming as support for MMGW, leading a team of "researchers" (not scientists) to read, not the scientific papers submitted in 2009, but mainly just the abstracts of the papers, and even then it was confirmed that his 'researchers' concluded the OPPOSITE position that the authors of the papers themselves were demonstrating, something like 60% of the time. The Cook assertion that "97% of Scientists agree" is not science, it is bald-faced propaganda meant to appeal to the listener's cognitive bias (bandwagon fallacy). (Or in most cases, blind religious belief that we humans are evil, harmful parasites on the earth)

Wanna know why the 97%-myth is even dumber to use? Even if the 97% myth were true, "consensus" does not equal "truth". At one point it was the "Scientific consensus" that the Earth was the center of the Solar System. Did that mean that was true? 

Nope. 

It was the "Scientific consensus" at one time that if you got sick, doctors should cut you and let you bleed out the sickness. Was that true?

Nope.

For someone to point to this 97% myth as supportive evidence of the truthfulness of their weird neo-pagan religion, it's either ignorance or dishonesty. It's just pathetic.

Come on, Bill, I love ya, but if your side is right, if there is real reason and evidence that you can stand on, why this weird need to keep endlessly spitting out the debunked 97% factoid? Because MMGW has NOTHING TO DO WITH SCIENCE. It is a political agenda that is being pushed on us, using our good intentions against us. 

People who actually value truth over cognitive biased-affirming myths won't fall for this crap. So sad to see Bill relentlessly pushing this. :-(

text:
"most of these slight changes are caused by small variations in the Earth's orbit." He's talking about the ice ages cause by the Milankovitch Cycles. I'd hardly call a mile of ice over Manhattan a slight change in the climate. 

"Oceans provide 50% of the Earth's oxygen." No, they provide ~50% of the oxygen produced by photosynthesis that converts the 0.04% of the atmosphere that is CO2. So the oceans are responsible for half of that, or 0.1% of the oxygen. All the carbon in the world's biomass (<5,000Gt) couldn't consume even 1% of the oxygen in our atmosphere (1,000,000Gt). Plants don't make our oxygen.

The rate of sea level rise has not doubled. The rate measured by satellites is twice that measured by tide gauges due to their different methods. That doesn't mean the rate double when we launched the satellites. He's right that sea level may be rising because the oceans are warming, but that warming started long before we started burning fossil fuels. The tide gauges tell us that the rate of rise today is the same as it was during the Lincoln administration. Whatever is warming the oceans can't be the CO2 we emit, 85% of which has been emitted since 1950.

Tornadoes and hurricanes are in decline.

Locally grown foods have a larger carbon footprint than food produced by industrial agriculture.

Bill Nye is not a science guy.

text:
Let's look at it in a different perspective.¬†
If we do take action on climate change, & there turns out to be no climate change, then worst case scenario would be wasted money & a global depression.

If we don't take action on climate change, & there turns out to be no climate change, then we will continue with 'prosperity' & climate change won't be one of our problems.

If we do take action on climate change, & there turns out to BE climate change, we would have money well spent as we counteracted the effects of climate change somewhat. Its a different world, but its liveable.

If we don't take action on climate change, & there turns out to BE climate change, then we will have economic, political, social, environmental, & public health catastrophies on a global scale. Widespread warfare, scarce resources, & mass species extinction. Famines, huge heat waves, diseases, permanent economic collapse, & a horrible future for all of humanity & all other species.

I don't know about you, but considering the best & worst case scenarios, I'll take my chances with DOING something about climate change. Even if it is some pointless conspiracy to tax people or whatever.

text:
¬†@MaximvsDread¬†
1) You do realize current extinction rates are around 1000x the usual background rates of extinction right? It's kind of the main reason why people are wondering if we should consider this the next great extinction event.

2) "What's truely sad is that people like you think you can stop evolution with a tax increase"

Pretty sure no one's making this argument. I'm also pretty sure that you don't seem to realize how slow natural processes usually operate on this scale and how much time evolution takes to operate on populations. Even punctuated equilibrium takes a long time assuming you don't want to suffer from the bottleneck effect similar to what cheetahs are currently going through

3) "In the last 30 years I've seen the disappearence of Ducks, Crows and Pigeons just to mention a few species in my home territory."

Well, if I'm going to be honest and say ¬†that could be a local phenomenon, but if you're talking about entire species going extinct with regards to the natural background you'd be lucky if you heard about one species going¬†extinct¬†in your life¬†time.

4) "Each generation grows up used to what is at the moment."

Kind of irrelevant to the topic, I'd rate this as a red herring. You could still make this argument if sea levels were 200 feet higher, large portions of the world became literally unlivable and we lost 70% of our farmland.

Most people argue that climate change is bad not only because of species extinction but because it will effect many areas of our lives and the lives of later generations irreversibly¬†and not insignificantly. Namely our food supplies/water supplies, severity of large weather events just to name a few.

Pollution is real in needs to be contained. But there is no scientific link between pollution in global warming. author: I moved from Whitmore lake to omaha, and Nebraska is much nicer than Michigan.

text:
¬†@I moved from Whitmore lake to omaha, and Nebraska is much nicer than Michigan.¬†
"¬†The climate does this every 500 years."
Uh, no when it comes to global average temperatures it usually takes thousands of years to see natural temperature changes of the scale we've seen in recent history.

We've had plenty of redistribution of the same amount of energy with little global temperature change and large local swings, but that's not the same as changing the overall energy in the system.

".unfortunately, humans have only recorded weather patterns accurately for 98 years"

So you accept proxies for determining past climate when it comes to claiming how climate changes in the past, but you don't accept it here because....reasons?

All the same the pattern of warming in question is within the instrumental record. The reason why we can determine the mechanism is because each type of warming has a different fingerprint. Carbon based gases as the primary mechanism has been tested and confirmed to a fairly high degree of certainty as the primary cause because of predictions of this specific finger print.

text:
¬†@Jesse Jennings¬†
"you are the ones who are like the climate is changing it must be humans."

We know to a pretty high degree of certainty that we're responsible for most of the warming in the later half of the century because of science.

We know how it's been warming, we understand and have tested the mechanism by which it's been warming, we know where it's warming the quickest based upon the mechanism and have direct measurements that were predicted by the specific proposed mechanism. That's why we know it's primarily because of humans, not because of a post hoc ergo propter hoc argument.

"nice try on switching my argument back on me"
No, it's pointing out your reasoning is flawed because it's x happened without humans in the past therefore x cannot happen because of humans now.

I merely used the example of fire to point out why this is a poor argument.

text:
¬†@Jesse Jennings¬†
"Polar shift for starters."

Throwing shit out doesn't make it a valid alternative.

The reason why seeing "HOW" it's warming and testing the proposed mechanisms based on the observations does.

You'll note that a lot of what I've been saying is talking about the predictions based upon the specific mechanism which has already been confirmed.

It's perfectly fine to want to study more on a topic to know it on a more granular level, but pretending that the evidence isn't there when there's a vast body of it and all of it independently points towards a given mechanism goes from skepticism to denialism.

"I bet you didn't question these scientists "findings"."

You know, there are many things none of us will ever be able to fully verify, like I'm told that satellites are calibrated to account for general relativity as they orbit the earth, but there's no way I can confirm that they are but I don't assume they're lying because I can't, I do accept the likelihood to a high degree of certainty though.

The same deal applies to climate change, the vast body of evidence and relevant experts indicate a specific mechanism to a high degree of certainty, I understand the mechanism, the predictions, and relevant observations. Short of me doing all of the relevant science and observations myself I am fairly certain of the cause the same way I'm fairly certain that the effects of gravity and speed affects time.

"we have more icecaps than ever before."

Source? The antarctic, well the eastern part of the Antarctic is the furthest extent, everywhere else is significantly low and the Arctic is on track for being ice free during the summer by the 30's-40's, though the IPCC says this won't happen till after 2100 with current estimates. If you're referring to Arctic ice being thicker than last year....so what...>30 year downwards trend and it spikes up a year or two so obviously it's on the road to recovery for reasons?

http://nsidc.org/arcticseaicenews/
http://psc.apl.uw.edu/research/projects/arctic-sea-ice-volume-anomaly/

I can cherry pick a lot of extreme lows and claim it's been recovering in following years, but clearly the long term trend is down for the arctic just as one example.

And we're right back to the fire argument, again an actual skeptic would address the mechanism of how it's been warming rather than stating "x or y happened in the past therefore x or y cannot be caused by humans today"

Again, we can determine mechanisms by specific fingerprints of how it's warming. We also know those historical causes are not at play today. Ironically past events like the Laschamp anomaly are exactly why we are fairly certain that a flip in the poles will not have a significant effect on average climate.

Stating "things have changed in the past" matter little if you want to ignore all of the context that goes with that past. It's like people justifying the statement "it won't be that bad because it's been warmer in the past" ignoring that some of the same time periods they're talking about sea level rise was over 200 feet higher in some cases or most of northern america and major parts of asia were suffering from mega droughts.

text:
+wizardnug2
Well, it depends on the ice ages. For example the ways we exited snowball earth is CO2 would build up in the atmosphere from volcanic activity and not be sequestered into an ice covered ocean till CO2 concentrations got so high that it warmed the atmosphere enough to melt the multi mile thick ice.


For most cases in recent history natural factors, usually milankovitch cycles would change how much solar energy effects certain parts of the earth. To exit ice ages its various factors would result in more direct sunlight on the icy north and gradually warm the oceans. As the oceans warmed they gradually out gas CO2 which would mix in the atmosphere and delay heat dissipation which would create more warming and cause other feedbacks like long frozen biological mass decaying or frozen micro organisms producing methane and melt more ice till it reaches equilibrium or another forcing counter acts or reenforces the feedback loops.



The proper question you should be asking is "how do we know the mechanism that is causing the warming today". Different causes of warming have different finger prints of how it should warm. Like carbon gases will warm as much at night as much as the day, they'll warm at the poles, particularly higher latitudes quicker than at the equator, it'll warm the troposphere while cooling the stratosphere and a few other markers I can't remember off the top of my head. This is all actually within the instrumental record which is why the vast majority of relevant experts can point to the most likely cause of most of the warming over the last few decades.


If I were to say "it's the sun" well we have direct observations of the sun telling us this isn't the case, but even if it were, we'd expect the sun to warm areas like the equator faster, we'd expect it to warm at day faster than at night and we'd expect it to warm all of the layers of the atmosphere fairly uniformly. If you want to say cosmic rays, well there's no indication it's these either and historical events like the Laschamp anomaly indicate that cosmic rays don't really have a large effect on climate if they do at all. If you want to say it's orbital forces...well those won't be significant factors for another few thousand years and frankly happen a lot slower than we have been seeing within the instrumental record.

text:
I am kind of sad that Bill Nye did this video.  At worst, what we are doing now is hastening the process towards the next glacial period.  It's coming.  This planet has it's own cycles that will continue regardless of human activity.  One huge volcanic eruption would pollute more than our cumulative pollution and jump start the next ice age.  I'm not a fan of the big chemical companies that pollute all the time, but if worse comes to worse this planet will wipe us out with glaciers and rebalance the climate.

There are only 2 real reasons in my mind to reduce pollution now:  One is ethical, because destroying the environment is irresponsible.  The 2nd is a practical reason, giving us a few more years to get ready for a major change in how we live to prepare for a long, long winter.
