text:
You know what? No. I will flood you with the evidence that people from my grandfathers generation were not stupid like you assume them to be and were well aware of environmental changes and the dangers of them AND how it would impact future generations. First,  In New England (where my entire lineage is from and resides today) , many farmers became uneasy as they noticed clearing of forest changed stream flows and a decrease in bird population which helped control insects and other pests. These concerns become widely known with the publication of Man and Nature released in 1864 by George Perkins Marsh (57 years before my grandfather was born). The environmental impact method was used to determine how to proceed in situations that are detrimental to the environment by choosing the way that is least damaging and has the fewest lasting implications. In the 1870s sportsman magazines such as American Sportsmen, Forest and Stream, and Field and Stream led to the growth of the conservation movement. This conservation movement also urged the establishment of state and national parks and forests, wildlife refuges, and national monuments intended to preserve noteworthy natural features. Conservation groups focus primarily on an issue that's origins are routed in general expansion. As Industrialization became more prominent as well as the increasing trend towards Urbanization the conservative environmental movement began. Contrary to popular belief conservation groups are not against expansion in general, instead they are concerned with efficiency with resources and land development. Conservation first became a national issue during the progressive era's conservation movement 1890s - 1920s (Right around then my Pappy was born). My Pappy was born in the U.S. when the environmental movement was well under way. He was born into an environmentally conscious society. Theodore Roosevelt became a prominent conservationist, putting the issue high on the national agenda. He worked with all the major figures of the movement, especially his chief adviser on the matter, Gifford Pinchot. Roosevelt was deeply committed to conserving natural resources, and is considered to be the nation's first conservation President. He encouraged the Newlands Reclamation Act of 1902 to promote federal construction of dams to irrigate small farms and placed 230 million acres under federal protection. Roosevelt set aside more Federal land for national parks and nature preserves than all of his predecessors combined. In May 1908, Roosevelt sponsored the Conference of Governors held in the White House, with a focus on natural resources and their most efficient use. Roosevelt delivered the opening address: "Conservation as a National Duty.". Other influential conservationists of the Progressive Era included George Bird Grinnell (a prominent sportsmen who founded the Boone and Crockett Club), the Izaak Walton League and John Muir, the founder of the Sierra Club in 1892. Conservationists organized the National Parks Conservation Association, the Audubon Society, and other groups that still remain active. Franklin Delano Roosevelt (1933‚Äì45), like his cousin Theodore Roosevelt, was an ardent conservationist. He used numerous programs of the departments of Agriculture and Interior to end wasteful land-use, mitigate the effects of the Dust Bowl, and efficiently develop natural resources in the West. One of the most popular of all New Deal programs was the Civilian Conservation Corps (1933‚Äì1943 when my Pappy was 11), which sent two million poor young men to work in rural and wilderness areas, primarily on conservation projects. The Inter-American Conference on the Conservation of Renewable Natural Resources met in 1948 (Pappy is 27 years old and 2 years from having a baby boy) as a collection of nearly 200 scientists from all over the Americans forming the trusteeship principle that:

"No generation can exclusively own the renewable resources by which it lives. We hold the commonwealth in trust for prosperity, and to lessen or destroy it is to commit treason against the future"

So there you have it. I need go no further. By 1948, before his first child was born, the message was starting to spread. Treason against the future. Well it doesn't take a genius to realize what that means. It is not time the are worried about but the people in it. But I digress and will go on.

During the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s, several events occurred which raised the public awareness of harm to the environment caused by man. In 1954, the 23 man crew of the Japanese fishing vessel Lucky Dragon was exposed to radioactive fallout from a hydrogen bomb test at Bikini Atoll, in 1969, an ecologically catastrophic oil spill from an offshore well in California's Santa Barbara Channel, Barry Commoner's protest against nuclear testing, Rachel Carson's book Silent Spring, Paul R. Ehrlich's The Population Bomb all added anxiety about the environment. Pictures of Earth from space emphasized that the earth was small and fragile.

As the public became more aware of environmental issues, concern about air pollution, water pollution, solid waste disposal, dwindling energy resources, radiation, pesticide poisoning (particularly as described in Rachel Carson's influential Silent Spring, 1962), noise pollution, and other environmental problems engaged a broadening number of sympathizers. That public support for environmental concerns was widespread became clear in the Earth Day demonstrations of 1970. Five years before I, my grandfathers grandson, was born. Prior to the 1970s the protection of basic air and water supplies was a matter mainly left to each state. During the 1970s, primary responsibility for clean air and water shifted to the federal government. Growing concerns, both environmental and economic, from cities and towns as well as sportsman and other local groups, and senators such as Maine's Edmund S. Muskie, led to passage of extensive legislation, notably the Clean Air Act of 1970 and the Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972. Other legislation included National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), signed into law in 1970, which established a United States Environmental Protection Agency and a Council on Environmental Quality; the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972; the Endangered Species Act of 1973, the Safe Drinking Water Act (1974) all before I was born. 

So publications had been made, clubs had been formed, presidents and scientists spoke of it publicly, bills passed, acts enacted, committees formed, laws passed threats of treason to future generations made ALL BEFORE I WAS BORN and I can tell you from first hand conversation and the fact that my grandparents lived off the grid and self sustaining that they were well aware of what the stakes were. 

And with that I turn the floor over to you. To disprove my claim you must disprove all those things and the personal experience I had with my own Pappy. Have at it Champ.

text:
+4121ZON4  You are only the second person to mention The Standard Atmosphere.  I kept a copy of the US Standard Atmosphere (1962,1976) because it clarifies so much (and dismisses CO2 and methane and...as just trace gases).  There is also an International Standard Atmosphere, as you mentioned, and they agree on all the salient points of physics and chemistry.  There's no magic ping-pong of IR between molecules that make up 0.04%v (0.06%wt) of the atmosphere, and the claims of such magic is appropriate to astrology or pre-Renaissance theology, not science.

I realized there is an excellent analogy for the issue: Take 1,000,000 grains (about 11 kG) of typical beach sand.  Let it warm up (in the Sun or in a warm room) and measure the temperature.  Now take out 400 grains and replace them with 400 grains of black sand, and repeat the trial, with the new mix of 999,600 grains of white sand and 400 grains of black.  There will be no measurable difference in the sand temperatures in the two trials,  Then, after whatever warming is done, remove the sand of the two trials to a cool spot, and measure the decline in temperature over time.  I'm sure you won't be surprised to be unable to detect a difference that is not experimental error.  Do it again with wet sand, or add seltzer water so there's CO2 in there too.

I'd like to ask one thing...that you lose the all-caps shout.  People who don't understand English (or science) don't have a hearing problem.  They have a processing problem.

author: Jason Wood

text:
¬†@Jason Wood¬†
We are creatures of opportunity, no one could ever deny that! Then again, I did just get done arguing with a bunch of industry trolls who think they know more about science than scientists.

SO...

YES, warming would have happened eventually. It goes in regular cycles. Sometimes those cycles even prove catastrophic. The reality, however, is that we didn't have to push it... because, in so-doing, we have shortened the duration of change, and therefore increased its severity. THAT'S THE SCIENCE! And it's not that difficult to understand.

Now, I understand that there are many who do not want to believe in said science (at least, no one with vested business interests). However, that doesn't make the science any less real, or the consequences any less dire.

It comes down to this: If you define life as a complex collection of mechanisms, then you can (and should) just as readily define the earth itself as a living being. And like all living beings it has an immune system. If we trigger that immune system (as science is suggesting we have) then we should expect all manner of tragedies to befall us: hurricanes; floods; droughts; famines; possibly even earthquakes -- all of EPIC, some might even say BIBLICAL proportions. And if you take the latter stance, then you can't say you weren't warned! But, of course, that warning came from a source that is easily mocked, and even more easily disregarded in lieu of "PROGRESS" -- a term which refers more to the evolution of MONEY, than of anything LIVING.

So, the fight has ALWAYS been about stopping the machine before it devours everything in sight. And it always will be, for as long as the threat remains. And the threat is not hard to spot, as it always dresses in fancy clothes and expects everyone to wave its little flag!

text:
Anyway, I'll say again:
It's far more useful for everybody if you state not just what you believe, but why; and cite evidence which has led you to this conclusion, or simply provide it upon request.  If you disagree, state why and address the evidence, while providing your own, if possible.  Don't assume you know exactly what the other thinks, or you will overstep.  Politeness is practical, but some people don't share that knowledge.  These are a few characteristics of the most valuable conversation.  Also, boobs.

text:
¬†@invisibleaznDJ¬†¬†Admittedly, I'm no climate scientist.

And even if it's all over-dramatized... I still see nothing wrong with curbing the expulsion of CO2, etc. into our atmosphere.

Venus has been described as global warming gone loco... it's basic chemistry, that CO2 traps heat, etc. and since we keep pumping it into our atmosphere, while we've cut down most of the planet's forests...¬†according to the World Resources Institute, more than 80% of the Earth's natural forests already have been destroyed. Up to 90% of West Africa's coastal rain forests have disappeared since 1900.

Trees that soak up CO2 and release oxygen... our current preliminary CO2 level as of October averaged 398.29 ppm... it was just under 320 ppm in 1960.¬†The upper safety limit for atmospheric CO2 is 350 parts per million. Atmospheric CO2 levels have stayed higher than 350 ppm since early 1988.

Furthermore, I see nothing wrong with developing clean energy that doesn't pollute our environment... I mean, I think it'd be simple logic to people, but I guess not.
